<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> achilles <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in greek mythology , achilles or achilleus ( , achilleus ) was a hero of the trojan war , the greatest of all the greek warriors , and is the central character of homer s iliad . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> he was the son of the nereid thetis and peleus , king of phthia . achilles most notable feat during the trojan war was the slaying of the trojan prince hector outside the gates of troy . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> although the death of achilles is not presented in the iliad , other sources concur that he was killed near the end of the trojan war by paris , who shot him in the heel with an arrow . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> later legends ( beginning with statius unfinished epic achilleid , written in the 1st century ad ) state that achilles was invulnerable in all of his body except for his heel because , when his mother thetis dipped him in the river styx as an infant , she held him by one of his heels . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> alluding to these legends , the term achilles heel has come to mean a point of weakness , especially in someone or something with an otherwise strong constitution . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the achilles tendon is also named after him due to these legends . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> linear b tablets attest to the personal name achilleus in the forms a ki re u and a ki re we , the latter being the dative of the former . <end>
<start> the name grew more popular , even becoming common soon after the seventh century bc and was also turned into the female form ( achilleia ) , attested in attica in the fourth century bc ( ig ii 1617 ) and , in the form achillia , on a stele in halicarnassus as the name of a female gladiator fighting an amazon .
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> achilles name can be analyzed as a combination of ( ) distress , pain , sorrow , grief and ( ) people , soldiers , nation , resulting in a proto form akhi lauos he who has the people distressed or he whose people have distress . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the grief or distress of the people is a theme raised numerous times in the iliad ( and frequently by achilles himself ) . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> achilles role as the hero of grief or distress forms an ironic juxtaposition with the conventional view of him as the hero of ( glory , usually in war ) . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> furthermore , laos has been construed by gregory nagy , following leonard palmer , to mean a corps of soldiers , a muster . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> with this derivation , the name obtains a double meaning in the poem when the hero is functioning rightly , his men bring distress to the enemy , but when wrongly , his men get the grief of war . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the poem is in part about the misdirection of anger on the part of leadership . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> another etymology relates the name to a proto indo european compound h ek pods sharp foot which first gave an illyrian akpedios , evolving through time into akhpdeos and then akhiddeus . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the shift from dd to ll is then ascribed to the passing of the name into greek via a pre greek source . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the first root part h ek <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> sharp , pointed also gave greek ( ake point , silence , healing ) , ( akme point , edge , zenith ) and ( oxus sharp , pointed , keen , quick , clever ) , whereas stems from the root h eg to be upset , afraid . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the whole expression would be comparable to the latin acupedius swift of foot . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> compare also the latin word family of acies sharp edge or point , battle line , battle , engagement , acus needle , pin , bodkin , and acuo to make pointed , sharpen , whet to exercise to arouse ( whence acute ) . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> some topical epitheta of achilles in the iliad point to this swift footedness , namely ( podarkes dios achilleus swift footed divine achilles ) or , even more frequently , ( podas okus achilleus quick footed achilles ) . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> some researchers deem the name a loan word , possibly from a pre greek language . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> achilles descent from the nereid thetis and a similarity of his name with those of river deities such as acheron and achelous have led to speculations about him being an old water divinity ( see below worship ) . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> robert s . p . beekes has suggested a pre greek origin of the name , based among other things on the coexistence of and in epic language , which may account for a palatalized phoneme l in the original language . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> achilles was the son of the nereid thetis and of peleus , the king of the myrmidons . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> zeus and poseidon had been rivals for the hand of thetis until prometheus , the fore thinker , warned zeus of a prophecy ( originally uttered by themis , goddess of divine law ) that thetis would bear a son greater than his father . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> for this reason , the two gods withdrew their pursuit , and had her wed peleus . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> there is a tale which offers an alternative version of these events in the argonautica ( 4 . 760 ) zeus sister and wife hera alludes to thetis chaste resistance to the advances of zeus , pointing out that thetis was so loyal to hera s marriage bond that she coolly rejected the father of gods . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> thetis , although a daughter of the sea god nereus , was also brought up by hera , further explaining her resistance to the advances of zeus . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> zeus was furious and decreed that she would never marry an immortal . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> according to the achilleid , written by statius in the 1st century ad , and to non surviving previous sources , when achilles was born thetis tried to make him immortal by dipping him in the river styx . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> however , he was left vulnerable at the part of the body by which she held him his left heel ( see achilles heel , achilles tendon ) . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> it is not clear if this version of events was known earlier . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in another version of this story , thetis anointed the boy in ambrosia and put him on top of a fire in order to burn away the mortal parts of his body . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> she was interrupted by peleus and abandoned both father and son in a rage . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> however , none of the sources before statius make any reference to this general invulnerability . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> to the contrary , in the iliad homer mentions achilles being wounded in book 21 the paeonian hero asteropaeus , son of pelagon , challenged achilles by the river scamander . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> he cast two spears at once , one grazed achilles elbow , drawing a spurt of blood . <end>
<start> also , in the fragmentary poems of the epic cycle in which one can find description of the hero s death ( i . e . the cypria , the little iliad by lesches of pyrrha , the aithiopis and iliou persis by arctinus of miletus ) , there is no trace of any reference to his general invulnerability or his famous weakness
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> peleus entrusted achilles to chiron the centaur , on mount pelion , to be reared . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> thetis foretold that her son s fate was either to gain glory and die young , or to live a long but uneventful life in obscurity . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> achilles chose the former , and decided to take part in the trojan war . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> according to homer , achilles grew up in phthia together with his companion patroclus . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> according to photius , the sixth book of the new history by ptolemy hephaestion reported that thetis burned in a secret place the children she had by peleus but when she had achilles , peleus noticed , tore him from the flames with only a burnt foot , and confided him to the centaur chiron . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> later chiron exhumed the body of the damysus , who was the fastest of all the giants , removed the ankle , and incorporated it into achilles burnt foot . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> among the appellations under which achilles is generally known are the following <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> some post homeric sources claim that in order to keep achilles safe from the war , thetis ( or , in some versions , peleus ) hid the young man at the court of lycomedes , king of skyros . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> there , achilles is disguised as a girl and lives among lycomedes daughters , perhaps under the name pyrrha ( the red haired girl ) . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> with lycomedes daughter deidamia , whom in the account of statius he rapes , achilles there fathers a son , neoptolemus ( also called pyrrhus , after his father s possible alias ) . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> according to this story , odysseus learns from the prophet calchas that the achaeans would be unable to capture troy without achilles aid . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> odysseus goes to skyros in the guise of a peddler selling women s clothes and jewellery and places a shield and spear among his goods . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> when achilles instantly takes up the spear , odysseus sees through his disguise and convinces him to join the greek campaign . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in another version of the story , odysseus arranges for a trumpet alarm to be sounded while he was with lycomedes women while the women flee in panic , achilles prepares to defend the court , thus giving his identity away . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> according to the iliad , achilles arrived at troy with 50 ships , each carrying 50 myrmidons . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> he appointed five leaders ( each leader commanding 500 myrmidons ) menesthius , eudorus , peisander , phoenix and alcimedon . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> when the greeks left for the trojan war , they accidentally stopped in mysia , ruled by king telephus . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in the resulting battle , achilles gave telephus a wound that would not heal telephus consulted an oracle , who stated that he that wounded shall heal . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> guided by the oracle , he arrived at argos , where achilles healed him in order that he might become their guide for the voyage to troy . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> according to other reports in euripides lost play about telephus , he went to aulis pretending to be a beggar and asked achilles to heal his wound . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> achilles refused , claiming to have no medical knowledge . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> alternatively , telephus held orestes for ransom , the ransom being achilles aid in healing the wound . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> odysseus reasoned that the spear had inflicted the wound therefore , the spear must be able to heal it . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> pieces of the spear were scraped off onto the wound and telephus was healed . <end>
<start> according to the cypria ( the part of the epic cycle that tells the events of the trojan war before achilles wrath ) , when the achaeans desired to return home , they were restrained by achilles , who afterwards attacked the cattle of aeneas , sacked neighbouring cities ( like pedasus and lyrnessus , where the greeks capture the queen briseis )
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> however , the romance between troilus and chryseis described in geoffrey chaucer s troilus and criseyde and in william shakespeare s troilus and cressida is a medieval invention . <end>
<start> in dares phrygius account of the destruction of troy , the latin summary through which the story of achilles was transmitted to medieval europe , as well as in older accounts , troilus was a young trojan prince , the youngest of king priam s and hecuba s five legitimate sons ( or according other sources , another son of apollo ) .
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> despite his youth , he was one of the main trojan war leaders , a horse fighter or chariot fighter according to homer . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> prophecies linked troilus fate to that of troy <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> and so he was ambushed in an attempt to capture him . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> yet achilles , struck by the beauty of both troilus and his sister polyxena , and overcome with lust , directed his sexual attentions on the youth who , refusing to yield , instead found himself decapitated upon an altar omphalos of apollo thymbraios . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> later versions of the story suggested troilus was accidentally killed by achilles in an over ardent lovers embrace . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in this version of the myth , achilles death therefore came in retribution for this sacrilege . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> ancient writers treated troilus as the epitome of a dead child mourned by his parents . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> had troilus lived to adulthood , the first vatican mythographer claimed , troy would have been invincible . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> homer s iliad is the most famous narrative of achilles deeds in the trojan war . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> achilles wrath ( , menis achilleos ) is the central theme of the poem . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the first two lines of the iliad read the homeric epic only covers a few weeks of the decade long war , and does not narrate achilles death . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> it begins with achilles withdrawal from battle after being dishonoured by agamemnon , the commander of the achaean forces . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> agamemnon has taken a woman named chryseis as his slave . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> her father chryses , a priest of apollo , begs agamemnon to return her to him . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> agamemnon refuses , and apollo sends a plague amongst the greeks . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the prophet calchas correctly determines the source of the troubles but will not speak unless achilles vows to protect him . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> achilles does so , and calchas declares that chryseis must be returned to her father . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> agamemnon consents , but then commands that achilles battle prize briseis , the daughter of briseus , be brought to him to replace chryseis . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> angry at the dishonour of having his plunder and glory taken away ( and , as he says later , because he loves briseis ) , with the urging of his mother thetis , achilles refuses to fight or lead his troops alongside the other greek forces . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> at the same time , burning with rage over agamemnon s theft , achilles prays to thetis to convince zeus to help the trojans gain ground in the war , so that he may regain his honour . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> as the battle turns against the greeks , thanks to the influence of zeus , nestor declares that the trojans are winning because agamemnon has angered achilles , and urges the king to appease the warrior . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> agamemnon agrees and sends odysseus and two other chieftains , ajax and phoenix , to achilles with the offer of the return of briseis and other gifts . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> achilles rejects all agamemnon offers him and simply urges the greeks to sail home as he was planning to do . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the trojans , led by hector , subsequently push the greek army back toward the beaches and assault the greek ships . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> with the greek forces on the verge of absolute destruction , patroclus leads the myrmidons into battle , wearing achilles armour , though achilles remains at his camp . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> patroclus succeeds in pushing the trojans back from the beaches , but is killed by hector before he can lead a proper assault on the city of troy . after receiving the news of the death of patroclus from antilochus , the son of nestor , achilles grieves over his beloved companion s death . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> his mother thetis comes to comfort the distraught achilles . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> she persuades hephaestus to make new armour for him , in place of the armour that patroclus had been wearing , which was taken by hector . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the new armour includes the shield of achilles , described in great detail in the poem . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> enraged over the death of patroclus , achilles ends his refusal to fight and takes the field , killing many men in his rage but always seeking out hector . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> achilles even engages in battle with the river god scamander , who has become angry that achilles is choking his waters with all the men he has killed . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the god tries to drown achilles but is stopped by hera and hephaestus . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> zeus himself takes note of achilles rage and sends the gods to restrain him so that he will not go on to sack <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> troy itself before the time allotted for its destruction , seeming to show that the unhindered rage of achilles can defy fate itself . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> finally , achilles finds his prey . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> achilles chases hector around the wall of troy three times before athena , in the form of hector s favorite and dearest brother , deiphobus , persuades hector to stop running and fight achilles face to face . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> after hector realizes the trick , he knows the battle is inevitable . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> wanting to go down fighting , he charges at achilles with his only weapon , his sword , but misses . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> accepting his fate , hector begs achilles , not to spare his life , but to treat his body with respect after killing him . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> achilles tells hector it is hopeless to expect that of him , declaring that my rage , my fury would drive me now to hack your flesh away and eat you raw such agonies you have caused me . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> achilles then kills hector and drags his corpse by its heels behind his chariot . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> after having a dream where patroclus begs achilles to hold his funeral , achilles hosts a series of funeral games in his honour . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> at the onset of his duel with hector , achilles is referred to as the brightest star in the sky , which comes on in the autumn , orion s dog ( sirius ) a sign of evil . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> during the cremation of patroclus , he is compared to hesperus , the evening western star ( venus ) , while the burning of the funeral pyre lasts until phosphorus , the morning eastern star ( also venus ) has set ( descended ) . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> with the assistance of the god hermes ( argeiphontes ) , hector s father priam goes to achilles tent to plead with achilles for the return of hector s body so that he can be buried . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> achilles relents and promises a truce for the duration of the funeral , lasting 9 days with a burial on the 10th ( in the tradition of niobe s offspring ) . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the poem ends with a description of hector s funeral , with the doom of troy and achilles himself still to come . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the aethiopis ( 7th century bc ) and a work named posthomerica , composed by quintus of smyrna in the fourth century ad , relate further events from the trojan war . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> when penthesilea , queen of the amazons and daughter of ares , arrives in troy , priam hopes that she will defeat achilles . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> after his temporary truce with priam , achilles fights and kills the warrior queen , only to grieve over her death later . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> at first , he was so distracted by her beauty , he did not fight as intensely as usual . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> once he realized that his distraction was endangering his life , he refocused and killed her . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> following the death of patroclus , nestor s son antilochus becomes achilles closest companion . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> when memnon , son of the dawn goddess eos and king of ethiopia , slays antilochus , achilles once more obtains revenge on the battlefield , killing memnon . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> consequently , eos will not let the sun rise , until zeus persuades her . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the fight between achilles and memnon over antilochus echoes that of achilles and hector over patroclus , except that memnon ( unlike hector ) was also the son of a goddess . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> many homeric scholars argued that episode inspired many details in the iliad s description of the death of patroclus and achilles reaction to it . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the episode then formed the basis of the cyclic epic aethiopis , which was composed after the iliad , possibly in the 7th century bc . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the aethiopis is now lost , except for scattered fragments quoted by later authors . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the exact nature of achilles relationship with patroclus has been a subject of dispute in both the classical period and modern times . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in the iliad , it appears to be the model of a deep and loyal friendship . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> homer does not suggest that achilles and his close friend patroclus were lovers . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> despite there being no direct evidence in the text of the iliad that achilles and patroclus were lovers , this theory was expressed by some later authors . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> commentators from classical antiquity to the present have often interpreted the relationship through the lens of their own cultures . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in 5th century bc athens , the intense bond was often viewed in light of the greek custom of paiderasteia . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in plato s symposium , the participants in a dialogue about love assume that achilles and patroclus were a couple phaedrus argues that achilles was the younger and more beautiful one <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> so he was the beloved and patroclus was the lover . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> but ancient greek had no words to distinguish heterosexual and homosexual , and it was assumed that a man could both desire handsome young men and have sex with women . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> many pairs of men throughout history have been compared to achilles and patroclus to imply a homosexual relationship . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the death of achilles , even if considered solely as it occurred in the oldest sources , is a complex one , with many different versions . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in the oldest one , the iliad , and as predicted by hector with his dying breath , the hero s death was brought about by paris with an arrow ( to the heel according to statius ) . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in some versions , the god apollo guided paris arrow . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> some retellings also state that achilles was scaling the gates of troy and was hit with a poisoned arrow . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> all of these versions deny paris any sort of valour , owing to the common conception that paris was a coward and not the man his brother hector was , and achilles remained undefeated on the battlefield . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> his bones were mingled with those of patroclus , and funeral games were held . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> he was represented in the aethiopis as living after his death in the island of leuke at the mouth of the river danube . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> another version of achilles death is that he fell deeply in love with one of the trojan princesses , polyxena . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> achilles asks priam for polyxena s hand in marriage . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> priam is willing because it would mean the end of the war and an alliance with the world s greatest warrior . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> but while priam is overseeing the private marriage of polyxena and achilles , paris , who would have to give up helen if achilles married his sister , hides in the bushes and shoots achilles with a divine arrow , killing him . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in the odyssey , agamemnon informs achilles of his pompous burial and the erection of his mound at the hellespont while they are receiving the dead suitors in hades . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> he claims they built a massive burial mound on the beach of ilion that could be seen by anyone approaching from the ocean . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> achilles was cremated and his ashes buried in the same urn as those of patroclus . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> paris was later killed by philoctetes using the enormous bow of heracles . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in book 11 of homer s odyssey , odysseus sails to the underworld and converses with the shades . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> one of these is achilles , who when greeted as blessed in life , blessed in death , responds that he would rather be a slave to the worst of masters than be king of all the dead . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> but achilles then asks odysseus of his son s exploits in the trojan war , and when odysseus tells of neoptolemus heroic actions , achilles is filled with satisfaction . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> this leaves the reader with an ambiguous understanding of how achilles felt about the heroic life . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> according to some accounts , he had married medea in life , so that after both their deaths they were united in the elysian fields of hades as hera promised thetis in apollonius argonautica ( 3rd century bc ) . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> achilles armour was the object of a feud between odysseus and telamonian ajax <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> ( ajax the greater ) . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> they competed for it by giving speeches on why they were the bravest after achilles to their trojan prisoners , who after considering both men , decided odysseus was more deserving of the armour . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> furious , ajax cursed odysseus , which earned him the ire of athena . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> athena temporarily made ajax so mad with grief and anguish that he began killing sheep , thinking them his comrades . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> after a while , when athena lifted his madness and ajax realized that he had actually been killing sheep , ajax was left so ashamed that he committed suicide . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> odysseus eventually gave the armour to neoptolemus , the son of achilles . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> a relic claimed to be achilles bronze headed spear was for centuries preserved in the temple of athena on the acropolis of phaselis , lycia , a port on the pamphylian gulf . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the city was visited in 333 bc by alexander the great , who envisioned himself as the new achilles and carried the iliad with him , but his court biographers do not mention the spear . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> however , it was shown in the time of pausanias in the 2nd century ad . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> numerous paintings on pottery have suggested a tale not mentioned in the literary traditions . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> at some point in the war , achilles and ajax were playing a board game ( petteia ) . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> they were absorbed in the game and oblivious to the surrounding battle . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the trojans attacked and reached the heroes , who were saved only by an intervention of athena . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the tomb of achilles , extant throughout antiquity in troad , was venerated by thessalians , but also by persian expeditionary forces , as well as by alexander the great and the roman emperor caracalla . <end>
<start> achilles cult was also to be found at other places , e . g . on the island of astypalaea in the sporades , in sparta which had a sanctuary , in elis and in achilles homeland thessaly , as well as in the magna graecia cities of tarentum , locri and croton , accounting for an almost panhellenic cult to the hero
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the cult of achilles is illustrated in the 500 bc polyxena sarcophagus , where the sacrifice of polixena near the tumulus of achilles is depicted . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> strabo ( 13 . 1 . 32 ) also suggested that such a cult of achilles existed in troad <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the spread and intensity of the hero s veneration among the greeks that had settled on the northern coast of the pontus euxinus , today s black sea , appears to have been remarkable . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> an archaic cult is attested for the milesian colony of olbia as well as for an island in the middle of the black sea , today identified with snake island ( ukrainian , zmiinyi , near kiliya , ukraine ) . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> early dedicatory inscriptions from the greek colonies on the black sea ( graffiti and inscribed clay disks , these possibly being votive offerings , from olbia , the area of berezan island and the tauric chersonese ) attest the existence of a heroic cult of achilles from the sixth century bc onwards . <end>
<start> the cult was still thriving in the third century ad , when dedicatory stelae from olbia refer to an achilles pontarches ( , roughly lord of the sea , or of the pontus euxinus ) , who was invoked as a protector of the city of olbia , venerated on par with olympian gods such as the local apollo prostates , hermes agoraeus
<start> pliny the elder ( 23 79 ad ) in his natural history mentions a port of the ach i and an island of achilles , famous for the tomb of that man ( portus achaeorum , insula achillis , tumulo eius viri clara ) , situated somewhat nearby olbia and the dnieper bug estuary furthermore , at 125 roman miles from this island
<start> this last feature of pliny s account is considered to be the iconic spit , called today tendra ( or kosa tendra and kosa djarilgatch ) , situated between the mouth of the dnieper and karkinit bay , but which is hardly 125 roman miles ( c . 185 km ) away from the dnieper bug estuary , as pliny states . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> ( to the race course he gives a length of 80 miles , c . 120 km , whereas the spit measures c . 70 km today . ) <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in the following chapter of his book , pliny refers to the same island as achillea and introduces two further names for it leuce or macaron ( from greek island of the blest ) . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the present day measures , he gives at this point , seem to account for an identification of achillea or leuce with today s snake island . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> pliny s contemporary pomponius mela ( c . 43 ad ) tells that achilles was buried on an island named achillea , situated between the borysthenes and the ister , adding to the geographical confusion . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> ruins of a square temple , measuring 30 meters to a side , possibly that dedicated to achilles , were discovered by captain kritzikly in 1823 on snake island . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> a second exploration in 1840 showed that the construction of a lighthouse had destroyed all traces of this temple . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> a fifth century bc black glazed lekythos inscription , found on the island in 1840 , reads glaukos , son of poseidon , dedicated me to achilles , lord of leuke . <end>
<start> in another inscription from the fifth or fourth century bc , a statue is dedicated to achilles , lord of leuke , by a citizen of olbia , while in a further dedication , the city of olbia confirms its continuous maintenance of the island s cult , again suggesting its quality as a place of a supra regional hero veneration . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the heroic cult dedicated to achilles on leuce seems to go back to an account from the lost epic aethiopis according to which , after his untimely death , thetis had snatched her son from the funeral pyre and removed him to a mythical ( leuke nesos white island ) . <end>
<start> already in the fifth century bc , pindar had mentioned a cult of achilles on a bright island ( , phaenna nasos ) of the black sea , while in another of his works , pindar would retell the story of the immortalized achilles living on a geographically indefinite island of the blest together with other heroes such as his father peleus and
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> well known is the connection of these mythological fortunate isles ( , makaron nesoi ) or the homeric elysium with the stream oceanus which according to greek mythology surrounds the inhabited world , which should have accounted for the identification of the northern strands of the euxine with it . <end>
<start> guy hedreen has found further evidence for this connection of achilles with the northern margin of the inhabited world in a poem by alcaeus , speaking of achilles lord of scythia and the opposition of north and south , as evoked by achilles fight against the aethiopian prince memnon , who in his turn would be removed to his homeland by his mother
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the periplus of the euxine sea ( c . 130 ad ) gives the following details the greek geographer dionysius periegetes , who lived probably during the first century ad , wrote that the island was called leuce because the wild animals which live there are white . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> it is said that there , in leuce island , reside the souls of achilles and other heroes , and that they wander through the uninhabited valleys of this island this is how jove rewarded the men who had distinguished themselves through their virtues , because through virtue they had acquired everlasting honour . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> similarly , others relate the island s name to its white cliffs , snakes or birds dwelling there . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> pausanias has been told that the island is covered with forests and full of animals , some wild , some tame . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in this island there is also achilles temple and his statue . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> leuce had also a reputation as a place of healing . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> pausanias reports that the delphic pythia sent a lord of croton to be cured of a chest wound . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> ammianus marcellinus attributes the healing to waters ( aquae ) on the island . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> a number of important commercial port cities of the greek waters were dedicated to achilles . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> herodotus , pliny the elder and strabo reported on the existence of a town achilleion ( ) , built by settlers from mytilene in the sixth century bc , close to the hero s presumed burial mound in the troad . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> later attestations point to an achilleion in messenia ( according to stephanus byzantinus ) and an achilleios ( ) in laconia . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> nicolae densusianu recognized a connection to achilles in the names of aquileia and of the northern arm of the danube delta , called chilia ( presumably from an older achileii ) , though his conclusion , that leuce had sovereign rights over the black sea , evokes modern rather than archaic sea law . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the kings of epirus claimed to be descended from achilles through his son , neoptolemus . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> alexander the great , son of the epirote princess olympias , could therefore also claim this descent , and in many ways strove to be like his great ancestor . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> he is said to have visited the tomb of achilles at achilleion while passing troy . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in ad 216 the roman emperor caracalla , while on his way to war against parthia , emulated alexander by holding games around achilles tumulus . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the greek tragedian aeschylus wrote a trilogy of plays about achilles , given the title achilleis by modern scholars . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the tragedies relate the deeds of achilles during the trojan war , including his defeat of hector and eventual death when an arrow shot by paris and guided by apollo punctures his heel . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> extant fragments of the achilleis and other aeschylean fragments have been assembled to produce a workable modern play . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the first part of the achilleis trilogy , the myrmidons , focused on the relationship between achilles and chorus , who represent the achaean army and try to convince achilles to give up his quarrel with agamemnon only a few lines survive today . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in plato s symposium , phaedrus points out that aeschylus portrayed achilles as the lover and patroclus as the beloved phaedrus argues that this is incorrect because achilles , being the younger and more beautiful of the two , was the beloved , who loved his lover so much that he chose to die to revenge him . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the tragedian sophocles also wrote the lovers of achilles , a play with achilles as the main character . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> only a few fragments survive . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> towards the end of the 5th century bc , a more negative view of achilles emerges in greek drama euripides refers to achilles in a bitter or ironic tone in hecuba , electra , and iphigenia in aulis . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the philosopher zeno of elea centred one of his paradoxes on an imaginary footrace between swift footed achilles and a tortoise , by which he attempted to show that achilles could not catch up to a tortoise with a head start , and therefore that motion and change were impossible . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> as a student of the monist parmenides and a member of the eleatic school , zeno believed time and motion to be illusions . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the romans , who traditionally traced their lineage to troy , took a highly negative view of achilles . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> virgil refers to achilles as a savage and a merciless butcher of men , while horace portrays achilles ruthlessly slaying women and children . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> other writers , such as catullus , propertius , and ovid , represent a second strand of disparagement , with an emphasis on achilles erotic career . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> this strand continues in latin accounts of the trojan war by writers such as dictys cretensis and dares phrygius and in benoit de sainte maure s roman de troie and guido delle colonne s historia destructionis troiae , which remained the most widely read and retold versions of the matter of troy until the 17th century . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> achilles was described by the byzantine chronicler leo the deacon , not as hellene , but as scythian , while according to the byzantine author john malalas , his army was made up of a tribe previously known as myrmidons and later as bulgars . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> achilles has been frequently the subject of operas , ballets and related genres . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in films achilles has been portrayed in the following films and television series in 1890 , elisabeth of bavaria , empress of austria , had a summer palace built in corfu . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the building is named the achilleion , after achilles . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> its paintings and statuary depict scenes from the trojan war , with particular focus on achilles . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> abraham lincoln abraham lincoln ( february 12 , 1809 april 15 , 1865 ) was an american statesman and lawyer who served as the 16th president of the united states from 1861 until his assassination in april 1865 . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln led the nation through the american civil war , its bloodiest war and its greatest moral , constitutional , and political crisis . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> he preserved the union , abolished slavery , strengthened the federal government , and modernized the u . s . economy . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> born in kentucky , lincoln grew up on the frontier in a poor family . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> self educated , he became a lawyer , whig party leader , illinois state legislator and congressman . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in 1849 , he left government to resume his law practice , but angered by the success of democrats in opening the prairie lands to slavery , reentered politics in 1854 . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> he became a leader in the new republican party and gained national attention in 1858 for debating national democratic leader stephen a . douglas in the 1858 illinois senate campaign . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> he then ran for president in 1860 , sweeping the north and winning . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> southern pro slavery elements took his win as proof that the north was rejecting the constitutional rights of southern states to practice slavery . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> they began the process of seceding from the union . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> to secure its independence , the new confederate states of america fired on fort sumter , one of the few u . s . forts in the south . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln called up volunteers and militia to suppress the rebellion and restore the union . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> as the leader of the moderate faction of the republican party , lincoln confronted radical republicans , who demanded harsher treatment of the south war democrats , who rallied a large faction of former opponents into his camp anti war democrats ( called copperheads ) , who despised him and irreconcilable secessionists , who plotted his assassination . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln fought the factions by pitting them against each other , by carefully distributing political patronage , and by appealing to the american people . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> his gettysburg address became an iconic call for nationalism , republicanism , equal rights , liberty , and democracy . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> he suspended habeas corpus , and he averted british intervention by defusing the trent affair . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln closely supervised the war effort , including the selection of generals and the naval blockade that shut down the south s trade . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> as the war progressed , he maneuvered to end slavery , issuing the emancipation proclamation of 1863 ordering the army to protect escaped slaves , encouraging border states to outlaw slavery , and pushing through congress the thirteenth amendment to the united states constitution , which outlawed slavery across the country . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln managed his own re election campaign . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> he sought to reconcile his damaged nation by avoiding retribution against the secessionists . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> a few days after the battle of appomattox court house , he was shot by john wilkes booth , an actor and confederate sympathizer , on april 14 , 1865 , and died the following day . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> abraham lincoln is remembered as the united states martyr hero . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> he is consistently ranked both by scholars and the public as among the greatest u . s . presidents . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> abraham lincoln was born on february 12 , 1809 , as the second child of thomas lincoln and nancy hanks lincoln , in a one room log cabin on sinking spring farm near hodgenville , kentucky . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> he was a descendant of samuel lincoln , an englishman who migrated from hingham , norfolk , to its namesake , hingham , massachusetts , in 1638 . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> samuel s grandson and great grandson began the family s westward migration , passing through new jersey , pennsylvania , and virginia . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln s paternal grandfather and namesake , captain abraham lincoln , moved the family from virginia to jefferson county , kentucky , in the 1780s . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> captain lincoln was killed in an indian raid in 1786 . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> his children , including eight year old thomas , abraham s father , witnessed the attack . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> thomas then worked at odd jobs in kentucky and in tennessee , before settling with members of his family in hardin county , kentucky , in the early 1800s . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln s mother , nancy , is widely assumed to have been the daughter of lucy hanks , although no record documents this . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> thomas and nancy married on june 12 , 1806 , in washington county , and moved to elizabethtown , kentucky . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> they produced three children <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> sarah , born on february 10 , 1807 abraham , on february 12 , 1809 and thomas , who died in infancy . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> thomas lincoln bought or leased farms in kentucky . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> thomas became embroiled in legal disputes , and lost all but of his land in court disputes over property titles . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in 1816 , the family moved to indiana , where the survey process was more reliable and land titles were more secure . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> indiana was a free ( non slaveholding ) territory , and they settled in an unbroken forest in hurricane township , perry county . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> ( their land became part of spencer county , indiana , when the county was established in 1818 . ) <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in 1860 , lincoln noted that the family s move to indiana was partly on account of slavery , but mainly due to land title difficulties . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in kentucky and indiana , thomas worked as a farmer , cabinetmaker , and carpenter . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> he owned farms , town lots and livestock , paid taxes , sat on juries , appraised estates , served on country slave patrols , and guarded prisoners . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> thomas and nancy were members of a separate baptists church , which forbade alcohol , dancing , and slavery . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> overcoming financial challenges , thomas eventually obtained clear title to of land in what became known as the little pigeon creek community . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> on october 5 , 1818 , nancy lincoln died of milk sickness , leaving 11 year old sarah in charge of a household that included her father , 9 year old abraham , and dennis hanks , nancy s 19 year old orphaned cousin . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> ten years later , on january 20 , 1828 , sarah died while giving birth to a stillborn son . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln was very distraught over his sister s death . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> on december 2 , 1819 , thomas married sarah sally bush johnston , a widow from elizabethtown , kentucky , with three children of her own . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> abraham became close to his stepmother , whom he referred to as mother . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln disliked the hard labor associated with farm life . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> he was called lazy for all his reading , scribbling , writing , ciphering , writing poetry , etc . . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> his stepmother acknowledged he did not enjoy physical labor , but loved to read . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln was largely self educated . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> his formal schooling ( from travelling teachers ) was intermittent , totaling less than 12 months however , he was an avid reader and retained a lifelong interest in learning . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> family , neighbors , and schoolmates recalled that he read and reread the king james bible , aesop s fables , john bunyan s the pilgrim s progress , daniel defoe s robinson crusoe , <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> mason locke weems s the life of washington , and the autobiography of benjamin franklin , among others . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> teenaged lincoln took responsibility for chores . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> he accepted the customary practice that a son give his father all earnings from work outside the home until age 21 . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln became adept at using an axe . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> tall for his age , lincoln was strong and athletic . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> he became known for his strength and audacity after winning a wrestling match with the renowned leader of a group of ruffians known as the clary s grove boys . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in early march 1830 , partly out of fear of a milk sickness outbreak , several members of the extended lincoln family moved west to illinois , a free state , and settled in macon county , west of decatur . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> historians disagree on who initiated the move thomas lincoln had no obvious reason to do so . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> one possibility is that other members of the family , including dennis hanks , might not have matched thomas s stability and steady income . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> after the family relocated to illinois , abraham became increasingly distant from thomas , in part because of his father s lack of education , although occasionally lending him money . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in 1831 , as thomas and other family prepared to move to a new homestead in coles county , illinois , abraham left home . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> he lived in new salem for six years . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln and some friends took goods by flatboat to new orleans , where he witnessed slavery firsthand . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> according to some sources , lincoln s first romantic interest was ann rutledge , whom he met when he first moved to new salem these sources indicate that by 1835 , they were in a relationship but not formally engaged . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> she died on august 25 , 1835 , most likely of typhoid fever . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in the early 1830s , he met mary owens from kentucky . <end>

<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln was remarkably fond of children , and the lincolns were not considered to be strict with their own . <end>

<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in 1832 , lincoln and partner denton offutt bought a general store on credit in new salem , illinois . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> although the economy was booming , the business struggled and lincoln eventually sold his share . <end>
