<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> he could draw crowds as a raconteur , but he lacked an education , powerful friends , and money and lost the election . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln interrupted his campaign to briefly serve as a captain in the illinois militia ( during the black hawk war ) . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> he then returned to his campaign . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> at his first speech , he observed a supporter in the crowd under attack , grabbed the assailant by his neck and the seat of his trousers and tossed him . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln finished eighth out of 13 candidates ( the top four were elected ) , though he received 277 of the 300 votes cast in the new salem precinct . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln served as new salem s postmaster and later as county surveyor , all the while reading voraciously . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> he decided to become a lawyer and began teaching himself law by reading blackstone s commentaries on the laws of england and other law books . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> of his learning method , lincoln stated i studied with nobody . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> his second state legislature campaign in 1834 was successful . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> although he ran as a whig , many democrats favored him over a more powerful whig opponent . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln served four successive terms in the illinois house of representatives as a whig from sangamon county . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> he supported the construction of the illinois and michigan canal , later serving as a canal commissioner . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in the 1835 36 legislative session , he voted to expand suffrage beyond white landowners to all white males . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> he was known for his free soil stance of opposing both slavery and abolitionism . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> he first articulated this in 1837 , saying , the institution of slavery is founded on both injustice and bad policy , but the promulgation of abolition doctrines tends rather to increase than abate its evils . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> he followed henry clay in supporting the american colonization society program of advocating abolition and helping freed slaves to settle in liberia . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> admitted to the illinois bar in 1836 , he moved to springfield , illinois , and began to practice law under john t . stuart , mary todd s cousin . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln developed a reputation as a formidable adversary during cross examinations and closing arguments . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> he partnered with stephen t . logan from 1841 until 1844 . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> then lincoln began his practice with william herndon , whom lincoln thought a studious young man . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> from the early 1830s , lincoln was a steadfast whig and professed to friends in 1861 to be an old line whig , a disciple of henry clay . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the party , including lincoln , favored economic modernization in banking , tariffs to fund internal improvements including railroads , and urbanization . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln ran for the whig nomination for illinois s 7th district of the u . s . house of representatives in 1843 , but was defeated by john j . hardin . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> however , lincoln won support for the principle of rotation , whereby hardin would retire after only one term . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln hoped that this arrangement would lead to his nomination in 1846 . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln was indeed elected to the house of representatives in 1846 , where he served one two year term . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> he was the only whig in the illinois delegation , showing party loyalty by participating in almost all votes and making speeches that echoed the party line . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln , in collaboration with abolitionist congressman joshua r . giddings , wrote a bill to abolish slavery in the district of columbia with compensation for the owners , enforcement to capture fugitive slaves , and a popular vote on the matter . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> he abandoned the bill when it failed to garner sufficient whig supporters . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> on foreign and military policy , lincoln spoke out against the mexican american war , which he attributed to president james k . polk s desire for military glory that attractive rainbow , that rises in showers of blood . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln supported the wilmot proviso , which if passed would have banned slavery in any u . s . territory won from mexico . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln emphasized his opposition to polk by drafting and introducing his spot resolutions . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the war had begun with a mexican slaughter of american soldiers in territory disputed by mexico , and polk insisted that mexican soldiers had invaded our territory and shed the blood of our fellow citizens on our own soil . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln demanded that polk show congress the exact spot on which blood had been shed and prove that the spot was on american soil . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> congress neither debated nor enacted the resolution , the national papers ignored it , and it cost lincoln political support in his district . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> one illinois newspaper derisively nicknamed him spotty lincoln . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln later regretted some of his statements , especially his attack on presidential war making powers . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> realizing clay was unlikely to win the presidency , lincoln , who had pledged in 1846 to serve only one term in the house , supported general zachary taylor for the whig nomination in the 1848 presidential election . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> taylor won and lincoln hoped to be appointed commissioner of the general land office , but lost out . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the administration offered him the consolation prize of secretary or governor of the oregon territory . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> this distant territory was a democratic stronghold , and acceptance of the post would have effectively ended his legal and political career in illinois , so he declined and resumed his law practice . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln practiced law in springfield , handling every kind of business that could come before a prairie lawyer . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> twice a year for 16 years , 10 weeks at a time , he appeared in county seats in the midstate region when the county courts were in session . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln handled transportation cases in the midst of the nation s western expansion , particularly river barge conflicts under the many new railroad bridges . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> as a riverboat man , lincoln initially favored those interests , but ultimately represented whoever hired him . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> he later represented a bridge company against a riverboat company in a landmark case involving a canal boat that sank after hitting a bridge . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in 1849 , he received a patent for a flotation device for the movement of boats in shallow water . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the idea was never commercialized , but lincoln is the only president to hold a patent . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in 1851 , he represented the alton sangamon railroad in a dispute with shareholder james a . barret , who had refused to pay the balance on his pledge to buy shares on the grounds that the company had changed its original train route . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln successfully argued that the railroad company was not bound by its original charter the charter was amended in the public interest to provide a newer , superior , and less expensive route , and the corporation retained the right to demand barret s payment . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the decision by the illinois supreme court was cited by many other courts . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln appeared before the illinois supreme court in 175 cases , in 51 as sole counsel , of which 31 were decided in his favor . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> from 1853 to 1860 , another of lincoln s largest clients was the illinois central railroad . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln s legal reputation gave rise to his nickname honest abe . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln s most notable criminal trial occurred in 1858 when he defended william duff armstrong , who was on trial for the murder of james preston metzker . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the case is famous for lincoln s use of a fact established by judicial notice in order to challenge the credibility of an eyewitness . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> after an opposing witness testified to seeing the crime in the moonlight , lincoln produced a farmers almanac showing the moon was at a low angle , drastically reducing visibility . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> armstrong was acquitted . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln rarely raised objections but in an 1859 case , where he defended a cousin , peachy harrison , who was accused of killing a man , lincoln angrily protested the judge s decision to exclude evidence favorable to his client . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> instead of holding lincoln in contempt of court as was expected , the judge , a democrat , reversed his ruling , allowing the evidence and acquitting harrison . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the debate over the status of slavery in the territories exacerbated sectional tensions between the slave holding south and the free north . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the compromise of 1850 failed to defuse the issue . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in the early 1850s , lincoln supported sectional mediation , and his 1852 eulogy for clay focused on the latter s support for gradual emancipation and opposition to both extremes on the slavery issue . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> as the 1850s progressed , the debate over slavery in the nebraska territory and kansas territory became particularly acrimonious , and senator douglas proposed popular sovereignty as a compromise measure the proposal would allow the electorate of each territory to decide the status of slavery . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the proposal alarmed many northerners , who hoped to prevent the spread of slavery into the territories . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> despite this northern opposition , douglas s kansas nebraska act narrowly passed congress in may 1854 . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> for months after its passage , lincoln did not publicly comment , but he came to strongly oppose it . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> on october 16 , 1854 , in his peoria speech , lincoln declared his opposition to slavery , which he repeated en route to the presidency . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> speaking in his kentucky accent , with a powerful voice , he said the kansas act had a declared indifference , but as i must think , a covert real zeal for the spread of slavery . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> i cannot but hate it . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> i hate it because of the monstrous injustice of slavery itself . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> i hate it because it deprives our republican example of its just influence in the world . . . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln s attacks on the kansas nebraska act marked his return to political life . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> nationally , the whigs were irreparably split by the kansas nebraska act and other efforts to compromise on the slavery issue . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> reflecting the demise of his party , lincoln wrote in 1855 , i think i am a whig , but others say there are no whigs , and that i am an abolitionist . . . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> i do no more than oppose the extension of slavery . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> drawing on the antislavery portion of the whig party , and combining free soil , liberty , and antislavery democratic party members , the new republican party formed as a northern party dedicated to antislavery . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln resisted early recruiting attempts , fearing that it would serve as a platform for extreme abolitionists . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln hoped to rejuvenate the whigs , though he lamented his party s growing closeness with the nativist know nothing movement . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in the 1854 elections , lincoln was elected to the illinois legislature but declined to take his seat . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in the elections aftermath , which showed the power and popularity of the movement opposed to the kansas nebraska act , lincoln instead sought election to the united states senate . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> at that time , senators were elected by the state legislature . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> after leading in the first six rounds of voting , he was unable to obtain a majority . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln instructed his backers to vote for lyman trumbull . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> trumbull was an antislavery democrat , and had received few votes in the earlier ballots his supporters , also antislavery democrats , had vowed not to support any whig . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln s decision to withdraw enabled his whig supporters and trumbull s antislavery democrats to combine and defeat the mainstream democratic candidate , joel aldrich matteson . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in part due to the ongoing violent political confrontations in kansas , opposition to the kansas nebraska act remained strong throughout the north . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> as the 1856 elections approached , lincoln joined the republicans . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> he attended the may 1856 bloomington convention , which formally established the illinois republican party . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the convention platform asserted that congress had the right to regulate slavery in the territories and called for the immediate admission of kansas as a free state . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln gave the final speech of the convention , in which he endorsed the party platform and called for the preservation of the union . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> at the june 1856 republican national convention , lincoln received significant support to run for vice president , though the party nominated william dayton to run with john c . fremont . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln supported the republican ticket , campaigning throughout illinois . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the democrats nominated former ambassador james buchanan , who had been out of the country since 1853 and thus had avoided the slavery debate , while the know nothings nominated former whig president millard fillmore . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> buchanan defeated both his challengers . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> republican william henry bissell won election as governor of illinois . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln s vigorous campaigning had made him the leading republican in illinois . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> eric foner ( 2010 ) contrasts the abolitionists and anti slavery radical republicans of the northeast , who saw slavery as a sin , with the conservative republicans , who thought it was bad because it hurt white people and blocked progress . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> foner argues that lincoln was a moderate in the middle , opposing slavery primarily because it violated the republicanism principles of the founding fathers , especially the equality of all men and democratic self government as expressed in the declaration of independence . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in march 1857 , in dred scott v . sandford , supreme court chief justice roger b . taney wrote that blacks were not citizens and derived no rights from the constitution . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> while many democrats hoped that dred scott would end the dispute over slavery in the territories , the decision sparked further outrage in the north . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln denounced it , alleging it was the product of a conspiracy of democrats to support the slave power . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln argued , the authors of the declaration of independence never intended to say all were equal in color , size , intellect , moral developments , or social capacity , but they did consider all men created equal equal in certain inalienable rights , among which are life , liberty , and the pursuit of happiness . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> douglas was up for re election in 1858 , and lincoln hoped to defeat him . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> with the former democrat trumbull now serving as a republican senator , many in the party felt that a former whig should be nominated in 1858 , and lincoln s 1856 campaigning and willingness to support trumbull in 1854 had earned him favor . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> some eastern republicans favored douglas s re election in 1858 , since he had led the opposition to the lecompton constitution , which would have admitted kansas as a slave state . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> many illinois republicans resented this eastern interference . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> for the first time , illinois republicans held a convention to agree upon a senate candidate , and lincoln won the nomination with little opposition . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> accepting the nomination , lincoln delivered his house divided speech , drawing on , a house divided against itself cannot stand . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> i believe this government cannot endure permanently half slave and half free . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> i do not expect the union to be dissolved <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start>  <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> i do not expect the house to fall <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start>  <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> but i do expect it will cease to be divided . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> it will become all one thing , or all the other . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the speech created an evocative image of the danger of disunion . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the stage was then set for the campaign for statewide election of the illinois legislature which would , in turn , select lincoln or douglas . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> when informed of lincoln s nomination , douglas stated , lincoln is the strong man of the party . . . and if i beat him , my victory will be hardly won . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the senate campaign featured seven debates , the most famous political debates in american history . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the principals stood in stark contrast both physically and politically . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln warned that the slave power was threatening the values of republicanism , and accused douglas of distorting the values of the founding fathers that all men are created equal , while douglas emphasized his freeport doctrine , that local settlers were free to choose whether to allow slavery , and accused lincoln of having joined the abolitionists . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the debates had an atmosphere of a prize fight and drew crowds in the thousands . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln s argument was rooted in morality . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> he claimed that douglas represented a conspiracy to extend slavery to free states . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> douglas s argument was legal , claiming that lincoln was defying the authority of the u . s . supreme court and the dred scott decision . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> though the republican legislative candidates won more popular votes , the democrats won more seats , and the legislature re elected douglas . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln s articulation of the issues gave him a national political presence . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in may 1859 , lincoln purchased the illinois staats anzeiger , a german language newspaper that was consistently supportive most of the state s 130 , 000 german americans voted democratic but the german language paper mobilized republican support . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in the aftermath of the 1858 election , newspapers frequently mentioned lincoln as a potential republican presidential candidate , rivaled by william h . seward , salmon p . chase , edward bates , and simon cameron . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> while lincoln was popular in the midwest , he lacked support in the northeast , and was unsure whether to seek the office . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in january 1860 , lincoln told a group of political allies that he would accept the nomination if offered , and in the following months several local papers endorsed his candidacy . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> on february 27 , 1860 , new york party leaders invited lincoln to give a speech at cooper union to a group of powerful republicans . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln argued that the founding fathers had little use for popular sovereignty and had repeatedly sought to restrict slavery . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln insisted that morality required opposition to slavery , and rejected any groping for some middle ground between the right and the wrong . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> despite his inelegant appearance many in the audience thought him awkward and even ugly lincoln demonstrated intellectual leadership that brought him into contention . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> journalist noah brooks reported , no man ever before made such an impression on his first appeal to a new york audience . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> historian david herbert donald described the speech as a superb political move for an unannounced candidate , to appear in one rival s ( seward ) own state at an event sponsored by the second rival s ( chase ) loyalists , while not mentioning either by name during its delivery . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in response to an inquiry about his ambitions , lincoln said , the taste is in my mouth a little . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> on may 9 10 , 1860 , the illinois republican state convention was held in decatur . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln s followers organized a campaign team led by david davis , norman judd , leonard swett , and jesse dubois , and lincoln received his first endorsement . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> exploiting his embellished frontier legend ( clearing land and splitting fence rails ) , lincoln s supporters adopted the label of the rail candidate . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in 1860 , lincoln described himself i am in height , six feet , four inches , nearly lean in flesh , weighing , on an average , one hundred and eighty pounds dark complexion , with coarse black hair , and gray eyes . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> on may 18 , at the republican national convention in chicago , lincoln won the nomination on the third ballot , beating candidates such as seward and chase . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> a former democrat , hannibal hamlin of maine , was nominated for vice president to balance the ticket . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln s success depended on his campaign team , his reputation as a moderate on the slavery issue , and his strong support for whiggish programs of internal improvements and the tariff . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> pennsylvania put him over the top , led by pennsylvania iron interests who were reassured by his tariff support . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln s managers had focused on this delegation , while following lincoln s dictate to make no contracts that bind me . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> most republicans agreed with lincoln that the north was the aggrieved party , as the slave power tightened its grasp on the national government . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> throughout the 1850s , lincoln doubted the prospects of civil war , and his supporters rejected claims that his election would incite secession . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> douglas was selected as the candidate of the northern democrats . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> delegates from eleven slave states walked out of the democratic convention , disagreeing with douglas s position on popular sovereignty , and ultimately selected incumbent vice president john c . breckinridge as their candidate . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> a group of former whigs and know nothings formed the constitutional union party and nominated john bell of tennessee . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln and douglas competed for votes in the north , while bell and breckinridge primarily found support in the south . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln s campaign team carefully projected his image as an ideal candidate . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> michael martinez wrote prior to the republican convention , the lincoln campaign began cultivating a nationwide youth organization , the wide awakes , which it used to generate popular support throughout the country to spearhead voter registration drives , thinking that new voters and young voters tended to embrace new parties . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln s ideas of abolishing slavery grew , drawing more supporters . <end>

<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the goal was to demonstrate the superior power of free labor , whereby a common farm boy could work his way to the top by his own efforts . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the republican party s production of campaign literature dwarfed the combined opposition a chicago tribune writer produced a pamphlet that detailed lincoln s life , and sold 100 , 000 200 , 000 copies . <end>

<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> after the november election , secessionists planned to leave the union before he took office in march . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> on december 20 , 1860 , south carolina took the lead by adopting an ordinance of secession by february 1 , 1861 , florida , mississippi , alabama , georgia , louisiana , and texas had followed . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> six of these states declared themselves to be a sovereign nation , the confederate states of america and adopted a constitution . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the upper south and border states ( delaware , maryland , virginia , north carolina , tennessee , kentucky , missouri , and arkansas ) listened to , but initially rejected , the secessionist appeal . <end>

<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln rejected the idea , saying , i will suffer death before i consent . . . to any concession or compromise which looks like buying the privilege to take possession of this government to which we have a constitutional right . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln did tacitly support the proposed corwin amendment to the constitution , which passed congress before lincoln came into office and was then awaiting ratification by the states . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> that proposed amendment would have protected slavery in states where it already existed . <end>

<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln was open to the possibility of a constitutional convention to make further amendments to the constitution . <end>

<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the failure of the peace conference of 1861 signaled that legislative compromise was impossible . <end>

<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> on april 12 , 1861 , confederate forces fired on union troops at fort sumter and began the fight . <end>

<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> north carolina , tennessee , and arkansas followed over the following two months . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> secession sentiment was strong in missouri and maryland , but did not prevail kentucky remained neutral . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the fort sumter attack rallied americans north of the mason dixon line to defend the nation . <end>

<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> john merryman , a maryland official involved in hindering the u . s . troop movements , petitioned supreme court chief justice and marylander , roger b . taney , author of the dred scott opinion , to issue a writ of habeas corpus . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in june taney , acting as a circuit judge and not speaking for the supreme court , issued the writ , because in his opinion only congress could suspend the writ . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln continued the army policy that the writ was suspended in limited areas despite the ex parte merryman ruling . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> after the battle of fort sumter , lincoln took executive control of the war and formed an overall union military strategy . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln responded to this unprecedented political and military crisis as commander in chief , using unprecedented powers . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> he expanded his war powers , imposed a blockade on confederate ports , disbursed funds before appropriation by congress , suspended habeas corpus , and arrested and imprisoned thousands of suspected confederate sympathizers . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln was supported by congress and the northern public for these actions . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in addition , lincoln had to reinforce union sympathies in the border slave states and keep the war from becoming an international conflict . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the war dominated lincoln s time and attention . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> from the start , it was clear that bipartisan support would be essential to success , and that any compromise would alienate factions on both sides of the aisle , such as the appointment of republicans and democrats to command positions . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> copperheads criticized lincoln for refusing to compromise on slavery . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the radical republicans criticized him for moving too slowly in abolishing slavery . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> on august 6 , 1861 , lincoln signed the confiscation act that authorized judicial proceedings to confiscate and free slaves who were used to support the confederates . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in practice , the law had little effect , but it did signal political support for abolishing slavery . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in late august 1861 , general john c . fremont , the 1856 republican presidential nominee , without consulting his superiors in washington , proclaimed a very harsh martial law in missouri . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln cancelled the proclamation , saying its emancipation plan was political , lacking military necessity and a legal basis . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> after lincoln acted , union enlistments from maryland , kentucky , and missouri increased by over 40 , 000 . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in foreign policy , lincoln s main goal was to stop military aid to the confederacy . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln left most diplomatic matters to his secretary of state , william seward . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> at times seward was too bellicose , so for balance lincoln maintained a close working relationship with senate foreign relations committee chairman charles sumner . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the trent affair of late 1861 threatened war with great britain . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the u . s . navy had illegally intercepted a british mail ship , the trent , on the high seas and seized two confederate envoys britain protested vehemently while the u . s . cheered . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln ended the crisis by releasing the two diplomats . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> biographer james g . randall dissected lincoln s successful techniques lincoln painstakingly monitored the telegraph reports coming into war department . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> he tracked all phases of the effort , consulted with governors , and selected generals based on their success ( as well as their state and party ) . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in january 1862 , after many complaints of inefficiency and profiteering in the war department , lincoln replaced simon cameron with edwin stanton as war secretary . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> stanton centralized the war department s activities , auditing and cancelling contracts , saving the federal government 17 , 000 , 000 . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> stanton was a staunchly unionist , pro business , conservative democrat who moved toward the radical republican faction . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> he worked more often and more closely with lincoln than any other senior official . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> stanton and lincoln virtually conducted the war together , say thomas and hyman . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in terms of war strategy , lincoln articulated two priorities to ensure that washington was well defended , and to conduct an aggressive war effort leading to prompt , decisive victory . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> however major northern newspapers demanded more <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> they expected victory within 90 days . <end>

<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> occasionally mary would force him to take a carriage ride , concerned that he was working too hard . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln learned from reading his chief of staff general henry halleck s book , a disciple of the european strategist jomini he began to appreciate the critical need to control strategic points , such as the mississippi river . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln saw the importance of vicksburg and understood the necessity of defeating the enemy s army , rather than simply capturing territory . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> after the union rout at bull run and winfield scott s retirement , lincoln appointed major general george b . mcclellan general in chief . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> mcclellan then took months to plan his peninsula campaign . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> mcclellan s slow progress frustrated lincoln , as did his position that no troops were needed to defend washington . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> mcclellan blamed lincoln s holding troops back for his campaign s subsequent failure . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln went as far as meeting with general mcclellan in his home to discuss matters privately . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> once mcclellan heard lincoln was in his home , mcclellan stayed hidden away until lincoln left . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln removed mcclellan in march 1862 , after mcclellan offered unsolicited political advice . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in july lincoln elevated henry halleck . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln appointed john pope as head of the new army of virginia . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> pope complied with lincoln s desire to advance on richmond from the north , thus protecting washington from counterattack . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> pope was then soundly defeated at the second battle of bull run in the summer of 1862 , forcing the army of the potomac back to defend washington . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> despite his dissatisfaction with mcclellan s failure to reinforce pope , lincoln restored him to command of all forces around washington . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> two days after mcclellan s return to command , general robert e . lee s forces crossed the potomac river into maryland , leading to the battle of antietam in september . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the ensuing union victory was among the bloodiest in american history , but it enabled lincoln to announce that he would issue an emancipation proclamation in january . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln had waited for a military victory so that the proclamation would not be perceived as the product of desperation . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> mcclellan then resisted the president s demand that he pursue lee s army , while general don carlos buell likewise refused orders to move the army of the ohio against rebel forces in eastern tennessee . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln replaced buell with william rosecrans and , after the 1862 midterm elections , replaced mcclellan with ambrose burnside . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> both were presumably more supportive of the commander in chief . burnside , against presidential advice , launched an offensive across the rappahannock river and was defeated by lee at fredericksburg in december . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> desertions during 1863 came in the thousands and increased after fredericksburg . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln promoted joseph hooker . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the midterm elections in 1862 cost the republicans severe losses due to rising inflation , high taxes , rumors of corruption , suspension of habeas corpus , military draft law , and fears that freed slaves would come north and undermine the labor market . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the emancipation proclamation gained votes for republicans in rural new england and the upper midwest , but cost votes in the irish and german strongholds and in the lower midwest , where many southerners had lived for generations . <end>
<start> in the spring of 1863 , lincoln became optimistic about upcoming military campaigns to the point of thinking the end of the war could be near if a string of victories could be put together these plans included attacks by hooker on lee north of richmond , rosecrans on chattanooga , grant on vicksburg , and a naval assault on charleston . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> hooker was routed by lee at the battle of chancellorsville in may . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> he then resigned and was replaced by george meade as lee moved north . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> meade followed lee into pennsylvania and beat him in the gettysburg campaign , but then failed to follow up despite lincoln s demands . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> at the same time , grant captured vicksburg and gained control of the mississippi river , splitting off the far western rebel states . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the federal government s power to end slavery was limited by the constitution , which before 1865 , committed the issue to individual states . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln argued that slavery would end by preventing its expansion into new territories . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> he sought to persuade the states to accept compensated emancipation in return for their prohibition of slavery . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln believed that curtailing slavery would make it obsolete . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln rejected fremont s two emancipation attempts in august 1861 and one by major general david hunter in may 1862 , on the grounds that it was not within their power , and would upset loyal border states . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> on june 19 , 1862 , endorsed by lincoln , congress passed an act banning slavery on all federal territory . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in july , the confiscation act of 1862 was enacted , which set up court procedures to free the slaves of those convicted of aiding the rebellion . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> although lincoln believed this was not within congress s power , he approved the bill in deference to the legislature . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> he felt such action could be taken only by the commander in chief , using constitutional war powers , which he planned to do . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln discussed a draft of the emancipation proclamation with his cabinet . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> privately , lincoln concluded that the confederacy s slave base had to be eliminated . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> however , copperheads argued that emancipation was a stumbling block to peace and reunification . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> republican editor horace greeley of the new york tribune agreed . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln rejected this argument directly in his letter of august 22 , 1862 . <end>
<start> although he said he personally wished all men could be free , lincoln stated that the primary goal of his actions as president ( he used the first person pronoun and explicitly refers to his official duty ) was that of preserving the union the emancipation proclamation , issued on september 22 , 1862 , with effect on january 1 , 1863 ,
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln spent the next 100 days preparing the army and the nation for emancipation , while democrats rallied their voters by warning of the threat that freed slaves posed to northern whites . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> once the abolition of slavery in the rebel states became a military objective , union armies advancing south liberated three million slaves . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln s comment on the signing of the proclamation was i never , in my life , felt more certain that i was doing right , than i do in signing this paper . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln continued earlier plans to set up colonies for the newly freed slaves . <end>

<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> as a young man , lincoln was a religious skeptic . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> later in life , lincoln s frequent use of religious imagery and language might have reflected his own personal beliefs or might have been a device to reach his audiences , who were mostly evangelical protestants . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> he never joined a church , although he frequently attended with his wife . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> he was deeply familiar with the bible , and he both quoted and praised it . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> he was private about his beliefs and respected the beliefs of others . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln never made a clear profession of christian beliefs . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> however , he did believe in an all powerful god that shaped events and by 1865 was expressing those beliefs in major speeches . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in the 1840s , lincoln subscribed to the doctrine of necessity , a belief that asserted the human mind was controlled by some higher power . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in the 1850s , lincoln asserted his belief in providence in a general way , and rarely used the language or imagery of the evangelicals he regarded the republicanism of the founding fathers with an almost religious reverence . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> with the death of his son edward , lincoln more frequently expressed a need to depend on god . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the death of son willie in february 1862 may have caused lincoln to look toward religion for solace . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> after willie s death , lincoln considered why , from a divine standpoint , the severity of the war was necessary . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> he wrote at this time that god could have either saved or destroyed the union without a human contest . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> yet the contest began . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> and having begun , he could give the final victory to either side any day . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> yet the contest proceeds . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> on the day lincoln was assassinated , he reportedly told his wife he desired to visit the holy land . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> several claims have been made that lincoln s health was declining before the assassination . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> these are often based on photographs appearing to show weight loss and muscle wasting . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> one such claim is that he suffered from a rare genetic disorder , men2b , which manifests with a medullary thyroid carcinoma , mucosal neuromas and a marfanoid appearance . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> others simply claim he had marfan syndrome , based on his tall appearance with spindly fingers , and the association of possible aortic regurgitation , which can cause bobbing of the head ( demusset s sign ) based on blurring of lincoln s head in photographs , which required long exposure times . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> confirmation of this and other diseases could possibly be obtained via dna analysis of a pillow case stained with lincoln s blood , currently in possession of the grand army of the republic museum library in philadelphia , but as of 2009 , the museum refused to provide a sample for testing . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the successful reunification of the states had consequences for the name of the country . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the term the united states has historically been used , sometimes in the plural ( these united states ) , and other times in the singular , without any particular grammatical consistency . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the civil war was a significant force in the eventual dominance of the singular usage by the end of the 19th century . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> historians such as harry jaffa , herman belz , john diggins , vernon burton , and eric foner stress lincoln s redefinition of republican values . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> as early as the 1850s , a time when most political rhetoric focused on the constitution , lincoln redirected emphasis to the declaration of independence as the foundation of american political values what he called the sheet anchor of republicanism . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the declaration s emphasis on equality and freedom for all , in contrast to the constitution s tolerance of slavery , shifted the debate . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> regarding the 1860 cooper union speech , diggins notes , lincoln presented americans a theory of history that offers a profound contribution to the theory and destiny of republicanism itself . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> he highlights the moral basis of republicanism , rather than its legalisms . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> nevertheless , lincoln justified the war via legalisms ( the constitution was a contract , and for one party to get out of a contract all the other parties had to agree ) , and then in terms of the national duty to guarantee a republican form of government in every state . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> burton argues that lincoln s republicanism was taken up by the emancipated freedmen . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in lincoln s first inaugural address , he explored the nature of democracy . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> he denounced secession as anarchy , and explained that majority rule had to be balanced by constitutional restraints . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> he said a majority held in restraint by constitutional checks and limitations , and always changing easily with deliberate changes of popular opinions and sentiments , is the only true sovereign of a free people . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in surveys of u . s . scholars ranking presidents conducted since the 1940s , lincoln is consistently ranked in the top three , often as number one . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> a 2004 study found that scholars in the fields of history and politics ranked lincoln number one , while legal scholars placed him second after george washington . <end>

<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> he was viewed by abolitionists as a champion for human liberty . <end>

<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> schwartz argues that lincoln s american reputation grew slowly from the late 19th century until the progressive era ( 1900 1920s ) when he emerged as one of america s most venerated heroes , even among white southerners . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the high point came in 1922 with the dedication of the lincoln memorial on the national mall in washington , d . c . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in the new deal era , liberals honored lincoln not so much as the self made man or the great war president , but as the advocate of the common man who they claimed would have supported the welfare state . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in the cold war years , lincoln s image shifted to a symbol of freedom who brought hope to those oppressed by communist regimes . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <start> by the 1970s , lincoln had become a hero to political conservatives for his intense nationalism , support for business , his insistence on stopping the spread of human bondage , his acting in terms of lockean and burkean principles on behalf of both liberty and tradition , and his devotion to the principles of the founding fathers . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> as a whig activist , lincoln was a spokesman for business interests , favoring high tariffs , banks , infrastructure improvements , and railroads , in opposition to the agrarian democrats . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> william c . harris found that lincoln s reverence for the founding fathers , the constitution , the laws under it , and the preservation of the republic and its institutions strengthened his conservatism . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> james g . randall emphasizes his tolerance and moderation in his preference for orderly progress , his distrust of dangerous agitation , and his reluctance toward ill digested schemes of reform . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> randall concludes that , he was conservative in his complete avoidance of that type of so called radicalism which involved abuse of the south , hatred for the slaveholder , thirst for vengeance , partisan plotting , and ungenerous demands that southern institutions be transformed overnight by outsiders . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> by the late 1960s , some african american intellectuals , led by lerone bennett jr . , rejected lincoln s role as the great emancipator . <end>

<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> defenders , such as authors dirck and cashin , retorted that he was not as bad as most politicians of his day and that he was a moral visionary who deftly advanced the abolitionist cause , as fast as politically possible . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the emphasis shifted away from lincoln the emancipator to an argument that blacks had freed themselves from slavery , or at least were responsible for pressuring the government on emancipation . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> historian barry schwartz wrote in 2009 that lincoln s image suffered erosion , fading prestige , benign ridicule in the late 20th century . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> on the other hand , donald opined in his 1996 biography that lincoln was distinctly endowed with the personality trait of negative capability , defined by the poet john keats and attributed to extraordinary leaders who were content in the midst of uncertainties and doubts , and not compelled toward fact or reason . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in the 21st century , president barack obama named lincoln his favorite president and insisted on using lincoln s bible for his inaugural ceremonies . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lincoln has often been portrayed by hollywood , almost always in a flattering light . <end>

<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> while he is usually portrayed bearded , he first grew a beard in 1860 at the suggestion of 11 year old grace bedell . <end>
<start> the most famous and most visited memorials are lincoln s sculpture on mount rushmore lincoln memorial , ford s theatre , and petersen house ( where he died ) in washington , d . c . and the abraham lincoln presidential library and museum in springfield , illinois , not far from lincoln s home , as well as his tomb . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> sociologist barry schwartz argues that in the 1930s and 1940s , the memory of abraham lincoln was practically sacred and provided the nation with a moral symbol inspiring and guiding american life . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> during the great depression , he argues , lincoln served as a means for seeing the world s disappointments , for making its sufferings not so much explicable as meaningful . <end>
