<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> algerian cuisine is rich and diverse . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the country was considered as the granary of rome . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> it offers a component of dishes and varied dishes , depending on the region and according to the seasons . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the cuisine uses cereals as the main products , since they are always produced with abundance in the country . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> there is not a dish where cereals are not present . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> algerian cuisine varies from one region to another , according to seasonal vegetables . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> it can be prepared using meat , fish and vegetables . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> among the dishes known , couscous , chorba , rechta , chakhchoukha , berkoukes , shakshouka , mthewem , chtitha , mderbel , dolma , brik or bourek , garantita , lham hlou , etc . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> merguez sausage is widely used in algeria , but it differs , depending on the region and on the added spices . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> cakes are marketed and can be found in cities either in algeria , in europe or north america . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> however , traditional cakes are also made at home , following the habits and customs of each family . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> among these cakes , there are tamina , baklawa , chrik , garn logzelles , griouech , kalb el louz , makroud , mbardja , mchewek , samsa , tcharak , baghrir , khfaf , zlabia , aarayech , ghroubiya and mghergchette . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> algerian pastry also contains tunisian or french cakes . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> marketed and home made bread products include varieties such as kessra or khmira or harchaya , chopsticks and so called washers khoubz dar or matloue . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> other traditional meals sold often as street food include mhadjeb or mahjouba , karantika , doubara , chakhchoukha , hassouna , and t chicha . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in 2002 , algeria had inadequate numbers of physicians ( 1 . 13 per 1 , 000 people ) , nurses ( 2 . 23 per 1 , 000 people ) , and dentists ( 0 . 31 per 1 , 000 people ) . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> access to improved water sources was limited to 92 of the population in urban areas and 80 of the population in the rural areas . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> some 99 of algerians living in urban areas , but only 82 of those living in rural areas , had access to improved sanitation . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> according to the world bank , algeria is making progress toward its goal of reducing by half the number of people without sustainable access to improved drinking water and basic sanitation by 2015 . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> given algeria s young population , policy favors preventive health care and clinics over hospitals . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in keeping with this policy , the government maintains an immunization program . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> however , poor sanitation and unclean water still cause tuberculosis , hepatitis , measles , typhoid fever , cholera and dysentery . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the poor generally receive health care free of charge . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> health records have been maintained in algeria since 1882 and began adding muslims living in the south to their vital record database in 1905 during french rule . <end>
<start> since the 1970s , in a centralized system that was designed to significantly reduce the rate of illiteracy , the algerian government introduced a decree by which school attendance became compulsory for all children aged between 6 and 15 years who have the ability to track their learning through the 20 facilities built since independence , now the literacy rate is around 78
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> since 1972 , arabic is used as the language of instruction during the first nine years of schooling . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> from the third year , french is taught and it is also the language of instruction for science classes . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the students can also learn english , italian , spanish and german . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in 2008 , new programs at the elementary appeared , therefore the compulsory schooling does not start at the age of six anymore , but at the age of five . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> apart from the 122 private schools , the universities of the state are free of charge . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> after nine years of primary school , students can go to the high school or to an educational institution . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the school offers two programs general or technical . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> at the end of the third year of secondary school , students pass the exam of the baccalaureate , which allows once it is successful to pursue graduate studies in universities and institutes . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> education is officially compulsory for children between the ages of six and 15 . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in 2008 , the illiteracy rate for people over 10 was 22 . 3 , 15 . 6 for men and 29 . 0 for women . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the province with the lowest rate of illiteracy was algiers province at 11 . 6 , while the province with the highest rate was djelfa province at 35 . 5 . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> algeria has 26 universities and 67 institutions of higher education , which must accommodate a million algerians and 80 , 000 foreign students in 2008 . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the university of algiers , founded in 1879 , is the oldest , it offers education in various disciplines ( law , medicine , science and letters ) . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> 25 of these universities and almost all of the institutions of higher education were founded after the independence of the country . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> even if some of them offer instruction in arabic like areas of law and the economy , most of the other sectors as science and medicine continue to be provided in french and english . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> among the most important universities , there are the university of sciences and technology houari boumediene , the university of mentouri constantine , and university of oran es senia . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the university of abou bekr belkaid in tlemcen and university of batna hadj lakhdar occupy the 26th and 45th row in africa . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> list of atlas shrugged characters <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> this is a list of characters in ayn rand s novel atlas shrugged . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the following are major characters from the novel . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> dagny taggart is the protagonist of the novel . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> she is vice president in charge of operations for taggart transcontinental , under her brother , james taggart . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> given james incompetence , dagny is responsible for all the workings of the railroad . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> francisco d anconia is one of the central characters in atlas shrugged , an owner by inheritance of the world s largest copper mining operation . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> he is a childhood friend , and the first love , of dagny taggart . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> a child prodigy of exceptional talents , francisco was dubbed the climax of the d anconia line , an already prestigious family of skilled industrialists . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> he was a classmate of john galt and ragnar danneskjold and student of both hugh akston and robert stadler . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> he began working while still in school , proving that he could have made a fortune without the aid of his family s wealth and power . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> later , francisco bankrupts the d anconia business to put it out of others reach . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> his full name is given as francisco domingo carlos andres sebastian d anconia . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> john galt is the primary male hero of atlas shrugged . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> he initially appears as an unnamed menial worker for taggart transcontinental , who often dines with eddie willers in the employees cafeteria , and leads eddie to reveal important information about dagny taggart and taggart transcontinental . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> only eddie s side of their conversations is given in the novel . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> later in the novel , the reader discovers this worker s true identity . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> before working for taggart transcontinental , galt worked as an engineer for the twentieth century motor company , where he secretly invented a generator of usable electric energy from ambient static electricity , but abandoned his prototype , and his employment , when dissatisfied by an easily corrupted novel system of payment . <end>

<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> anthropology anthropology is the scientific study of humans and human behavior and societies in the past and present . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> social anthropology studies patterns of behaviour and cultural anthropology studies cultural meaning , including norms and values . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> linguistic anthropology studies how language influences social life . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> biological or physical anthropology studies the biological development of humans . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> archaeology , which studies human activity through investigation of physical evidence , is thought of as a branch of anthropology in the united states and canada , while in europe , it is viewed as a discipline in its own right or grouped under other related disciplines , such as history . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the abstract noun anthropology is first attested in reference to history . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> its present use first appeared in renaissance germany in the works of magnus hundt and otto casmann . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> their new latin derived from the combining forms of the greek words anthropos ( , human ) and logos ( , study ) . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> ( its adjectival form appeared in the works of aristotle . ) <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> it began to be used in english , possibly via french , by the early 18th century . <end>
<start> in 1647 , the bartholins , founders of the university of copenhagen , defined as follows sporadic use of the term for some of the subject matter occurred subsequently , such as the use by etienne serres in 1839 to describe the natural history , or paleontology , of man , based on comparative anatomy , and the creation of a chair in
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> various short lived organizations of anthropologists had already been formed . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the societe ethnologique de paris , the first to use ethnology , was formed in 1839 . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> its members were primarily anti slavery activists . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> when slavery was abolished in france in 1848 the societe was abandoned . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> meanwhile , the ethnological society of new york , currently the american ethnological society , was founded on its model in 1842 , as well as the ethnological society of london in 1843 , a break away group of the aborigines protection society . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> these anthropologists of the times were liberal , anti slavery , and pro human rights activists . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> they maintained international connections . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> anthropology and many other current fields are the intellectual results of the comparative methods developed in the earlier 19th century . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> theorists in such diverse fields as anatomy , linguistics , and ethnology , making feature by feature comparisons of their subject matters , were beginning to suspect that similarities between animals , languages , and folkways were the result of processes or laws unknown to them then . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> for them , the publication of charles darwin s on the origin of species was the epiphany of everything they had begun to suspect . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> darwin himself arrived at his conclusions through comparison of species he had seen in agronomy and in the wild . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> darwin and wallace unveiled evolution in the late 1850s . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> there was an immediate rush to bring it into the social sciences . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> paul broca in paris was in the process of breaking away from the societe de biologie to form the first of the explicitly anthropological societies , the societe d anthropologie de paris , meeting for the first time in paris in 1859 . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> when he read darwin , he became an immediate convert to transformisme , as the french called evolutionism . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> his definition now became the study of the human group , considered as a whole , in its details , and in relation to the rest of nature . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> broca , being what today would be called a neurosurgeon , had taken an interest in the pathology of speech . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> he wanted to localize the difference between man and the other animals , which appeared to reside in speech . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> he discovered the speech center of the human brain , today called broca s area after him . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> his interest was mainly in biological anthropology , but a german philosopher specializing in psychology , theodor waitz , took up the theme of general and social anthropology in his six volume work , entitled die anthropologie der naturvolker , 1859 1864 . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the title was soon translated as the anthropology of primitive peoples . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the last two volumes were published posthumously . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> waitz defined anthropology as the science of the nature of man . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> following broca s lead , waitz points out that anthropology is a new field , which would gather material from other fields , but would differ from them in the use of comparative anatomy , physiology , and psychology to differentiate man from the animals nearest to him . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> he stresses that the data of comparison must be empirical , gathered by experimentation . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the history of civilization , as well as ethnology , are to be brought into the comparison . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> it is to be presumed fundamentally that the species , man , is a unity , and that the same laws of thought are applicable to all men . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> waitz was influential among the british ethnologists . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in 1863 the explorer richard francis burton and the speech therapist james hunt broke away from the ethnological society of london to form the anthropological society of london , which henceforward would follow the path of the new anthropology rather than just ethnology . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> it was the 2nd society dedicated to general anthropology in existence . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> representatives from the french societe were present , though not broca . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in his keynote address , printed in the first volume of its new publication , the anthropological review , hunt stressed the work of waitz , adopting his definitions as a standard . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> among the first associates were the young edward burnett tylor , inventor of cultural anthropology , and his brother alfred tylor , a geologist . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> previously edward had referred to himself as an ethnologist subsequently , an anthropologist . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> similar organizations in other countries followed the anthropological society of madrid ( 1865 ) , the american anthropological association in 1902 , the anthropological society of vienna ( 1870 ) , the italian society of anthropology and ethnology ( 1871 ) , and many others subsequently . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the majority of these were evolutionist . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> one notable exception was the berlin society for anthropology , ethnology , and prehistory ( 1869 ) founded by rudolph virchow , known for his vituperative attacks on the evolutionists . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> not religious himself , he insisted that darwin s conclusions lacked empirical foundation . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> during the last three decades of the 19th century , a proliferation of anthropological societies and associations occurred , most independent , most publishing their own journals , and all international in membership and association . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the major theorists belonged to these organizations . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> they supported the gradual osmosis of anthropology curricula into the major institutions of higher learning . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> by 1898 the american association for the advancement of science was able to report that 48 educational institutions in 13 countries had some curriculum in anthropology . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> none of the 75 faculty members were under a department named anthropology . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> this meager statistic expanded in the 20th century to comprise anthropology departments in the majority of the world s higher educational institutions , many thousands in number . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> anthropology has diversified from a few major subdivisions to dozens more . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> practical anthropology , the use of anthropological knowledge and technique to solve specific problems , has arrived for example , the presence of buried victims might stimulate the use of a forensic archaeologist to recreate the final scene . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the organization has reached global level . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> for example , the world council of anthropological associations ( wcaa ) , a network of national , regional and international associations that aims to promote worldwide communication and cooperation in anthropology , currently contains members from about three dozen nations . <end>
<start> since the work of franz boas and bronis aw malinowski in the late 19th and early 20th centuries , social anthropology in great britain and cultural anthropology in the us have been distinguished from other social sciences by its emphasis on cross cultural comparisons , long term in depth examination of context , and the importance it places on participant observation or experiential
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> cultural anthropology , in particular , has emphasized cultural relativism , holism , and the use of findings to frame cultural critiques . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> this has been particularly prominent in the united states , from boas arguments against 19th century racial ideology , through margaret mead s advocacy for gender equality and sexual liberation , to current criticisms of post colonial oppression and promotion of multiculturalism . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> ethnography is one of its primary research designs as well as the text that is generated from anthropological fieldwork . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in great britain and the commonwealth countries , the british tradition of social anthropology tends to dominate . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in the united states , anthropology has traditionally been divided into the four field approach developed by franz boas in the early 20th century biological or physical anthropology social , cultural , or sociocultural anthropology and archaeology plus anthropological linguistics . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> these fields frequently overlap but tend to use different methodologies and techniques . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> european countries with overseas colonies tended to practice more ethnology ( a term coined and defined by adam f . kollar in 1783 ) . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> it is sometimes referred to as sociocultural anthropology in the parts of the world that were influenced by the european tradition . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> anthropology is a global discipline involving humanities , social sciences and natural sciences . <end>
<start> anthropology builds upon knowledge from natural sciences , including the discoveries about the origin and evolution of homo sapiens , human physical traits , human behavior , the variations among different groups of humans , how the evolutionary past of homo sapiens has influenced its social organization and culture , and from social sciences , including the organization of human social and cultural
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> early anthropology originated in classical greece and persia and studied and tried to understand observable cultural diversity . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> as such , anthropology has been central in the development of several new ( late 20th century ) interdisciplinary fields such as cognitive science , global studies , and various ethnic studies . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> according to clifford geertz , sociocultural anthropology has been heavily influenced by structuralist and postmodern theories , as well as a shift toward the analysis of modern societies . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> during the 1970s and 1990s , there was an epistemological shift away from the positivist traditions that had largely informed the discipline . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> during this shift , enduring questions about the nature and production of knowledge came to occupy a central place in cultural and social anthropology . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in contrast , archaeology and biological anthropology remained largely positivist . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> due to this difference in epistemology , the four sub fields of anthropology have lacked cohesion over the last several decades . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> sociocultural anthropology draws together the principle axes of cultural anthropology and social anthropology . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> cultural anthropology is the comparative study of the manifold ways in which people make sense of the world around them , while social anthropology is the study of the relationships among individuals and groups . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> cultural anthropology is more related to philosophy , literature and the arts ( how one s culture affects the experience for self and group , contributing to a more complete understanding of the people s knowledge , customs , and institutions ) , while social anthropology is more related to sociology and history . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in that , it helps develop an understanding of social structures , typically of others and other populations ( such as minorities , subgroups , dissidents , etc . ) . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> there is no hard and fast distinction between them , and these categories overlap to a considerable degree . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> inquiry in sociocultural anthropology is guided in part by cultural relativism , the attempt to understand other societies in terms of their own cultural symbols and values . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> accepting other cultures in their own terms moderates reductionism in cross cultural comparison . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> this project is often accommodated in the field of ethnography . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> ethnography can refer to both a methodology and the product of ethnographic research , i . e . an ethnographic monograph . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> as a methodology , ethnography is based upon long term fieldwork within a community or other research site . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> participant observation is one of the foundational methods of social and cultural anthropology . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> ethnology involves the systematic comparison of different cultures . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the process of participant observation can be especially helpful to understanding a culture from an emic ( conceptual , vs . etic , or technical ) point of view . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the study of kinship and social organization is a central focus of sociocultural anthropology , as kinship is a human universal . <end>
<start> sociocultural anthropology also covers economic and political organization , law and conflict resolution , patterns of consumption and exchange , material culture , technology , infrastructure , gender relations , ethnicity , childrearing and socialization , religion , myth , symbols , values , etiquette , worldview , sports , music , nutrition , recreation , games , food , festivals , and
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> comparison across cultures is a key element of method in sociocultural anthropology , including the industrialized ( and de industrialized ) west . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> cultures in the standard cross cultural sample ( sccs ) of world societies are biological anthropology and physical anthropology are synonymous terms to describe anthropological research focused on the study of humans and non human primates in their biological , evolutionary , and demographic dimensions . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> it examines the biological and social factors that have affected the evolution of humans and other primates , and that generate , maintain or change contemporary genetic and physiological variation . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> archaeology is the study of the human past through its material remains . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> artifacts , faunal remains , and human altered landscapes are evidence of the cultural and material lives of past societies . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> archaeologists examine this material remains in order to deduce patterns of past human behavior and cultural practices . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> ethnoarchaeology is a type of archaeology that studies the practices and material remain of living human groups in order to gain a better understanding of the evidence left behind by past human groups , who are presumed to have lived in similar ways . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> linguistic anthropology ( not to be confused with anthropological linguistics ) seeks to understand the processes of human communications , verbal and non verbal , variation in language across time and space , the social uses of language , and the relationship between language and culture . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> it is the branch of anthropology that brings linguistic methods to bear on anthropological problems , linking the analysis of linguistic forms and processes to the interpretation of sociocultural processes . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> linguistic anthropologists often draw on related fields including sociolinguistics , pragmatics , cognitive linguistics , semiotics , discourse analysis , and narrative analysis . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> one of the central problems in the anthropology of art concerns the universality of art as a cultural phenomenon . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> several anthropologists have noted that the western categories of painting , sculpture , or literature , conceived as independent artistic activities , do not exist , or exist in a significantly different form , in most non western contexts . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> to surmount this difficulty , anthropologists of art have focused on formal features in objects which , without exclusively being artistic , have certain evident aesthetic qualities . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> boas primitive art , claude levi strauss the way of the masks ( 1982 ) or geertz s art as cultural system ( 1983 ) are some examples in this trend to transform the anthropology of art into an anthropology of culturally specific aesthetics . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> media anthropology ( also known as the anthropology of media or mass media ) emphasizes ethnographic studies as a means of understanding producers , audiences , and other cultural and social aspects of mass media . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the types of ethnographic contexts explored range from contexts of media production ( e . g . , ethnographies of newsrooms in newspapers , journalists in the field , film production ) to contexts of media reception , following audiences in their everyday responses to media . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> other types include cyber anthropology , a relatively new area of internet research , as well as ethnographies of other areas of research which happen to involve media , such as development work , social movements , or health education . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> this is in addition to many classic ethnographic contexts , where media such as radio , the press , new media , and television have started to make their presences felt since the early 1990s . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> ethnomusicology is an academic field encompassing various approaches to the study of music ( broadly defined ) , that emphasize its cultural , social , material , cognitive , biological , and other dimensions or contexts instead of or in addition to its isolated sound component or any particular repertoire . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> visual anthropology is concerned , in part , with the study and production of ethnographic photography , film and , since the mid 1990s , new media . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> while the term is sometimes used interchangeably with ethnographic film , visual anthropology also encompasses the anthropological study of visual representation , including areas such as performance , museums , art , and the production and reception of mass media . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> visual representations from all cultures , such as sandpaintings , tattoos , sculptures and reliefs , cave paintings , scrimshaw , jewelry , hieroglyphics , paintings , and photographs are included in the focus of visual anthropology . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> economic anthropology attempts to explain human economic behavior in its widest historic , geographic and cultural scope . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> it has a complex relationship with the discipline of economics , of which it is highly critical . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> its origins as a sub field of anthropology begin with the polish british founder of anthropology , bronis aw malinowski , and his french compatriot , marcel mauss , on the nature of gift giving exchange ( or reciprocity ) as an alternative to market exchange . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> economic anthropology remains , for the most part , focused upon exchange . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the school of thought derived from marx and known as political economy focuses on production , in contrast . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> economic anthropologists have abandoned the primitivist niche they were relegated to by economists , and have now turned to examine corporations , banks , and the global financial system from an anthropological perspective . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> political economy in anthropology is the application of the theories and methods of historical materialism to the traditional concerns of anthropology , including , but not limited to , non capitalist societies . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> political economy introduced questions of history and colonialism to ahistorical anthropological theories of social structure and culture . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> three main areas of interest rapidly developed . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the first of these areas was concerned with the pre capitalist societies that were subject to evolutionary tribal stereotypes . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> sahlin s work on hunter gatherers as the original affluent society did much to dissipate that image . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the second area was concerned with the vast majority of the world s population at the time , the peasantry , many of whom were involved in complex revolutionary wars such as in vietnam . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the third area was on colonialism , imperialism , and the creation of the capitalist world system . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> more recently , these political economists have more directly addressed issues of industrial ( and post industrial ) capitalism around the world . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> applied anthropology refers to the application of the method and theory of anthropology to the analysis and solution of practical problems . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> it is a complex of related , research based , instrumental methods which produce change or stability in specific cultural systems through the provision of data , initiation of direct action , and or the formulation of policy . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> more simply , applied anthropology is the practical side of anthropological research it includes researcher involvement and activism within the participating community . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> it is closely related to development anthropology ( distinct from the more critical anthropology of development ) . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> anthropology of development tends to view development from a critical perspective . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the kind of issues addressed and implications for the approach simply involve pondering why , if a key development goal is to alleviate poverty , is poverty increasing ? <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> why is there such a gap between plans and outcomes ? <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> why are those working in development so willing to disregard history and the lessons it might offer ? <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> why is development so externally driven rather than having an internal basis ? <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in short , why does so much planned development fail ? <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> kinship can refer both to the study of the patterns of social relationships in one or more human cultures , or it can refer to the patterns of social relationships themselves . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> over its history , anthropology has developed a number of related concepts and terms , such as descent , descent groups , lineages , affines , cognates , and even fictive kinship . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> broadly , kinship patterns may be considered to include people related both by descent ( one s social relations during development ) , and also relatives by marriage . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> feminist anthropology is a four field approach to anthropology ( archeological , biological , cultural , linguistic ) that seeks to reduce male bias in research findings , anthropological hiring practices , and the scholarly production of knowledge . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> anthropology engages often with feminists from non western traditions , whose perspectives and experiences can differ from those of white european and american feminists . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> historically , such peripheral perspectives have sometimes been marginalized and regarded as less valid or important than knowledge from the western world . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> feminist anthropologists have claimed that their research helps to correct this systematic bias in mainstream feminist theory . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> feminist anthropologists are centrally concerned with the construction of gender across societies . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> feminist anthropology is inclusive of birth anthropology as a specialization . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the first african american female anthropologist and caribbeanist is said to be vera mae green who studied ethnic and family relations in the caribbean as well as the united states , and thereby tried to improve the way black life , experiences , and culture were studied . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> medical anthropology is an interdisciplinary field which studies human health and disease , health care systems , and biocultural adaptation . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> it is believed that william caudell was the first to discover the field of medical anthropology . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> currently , research in medical anthropology is one of the main growth areas in the field of anthropology as a whole . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> it focuses on the following six basic fields other subjects that have become central to medical anthropology worldwide are violence and social suffering ( farmer , 1999 , 2003 beneduce , 2010 ) as well as other issues that involve physical and psychological harm and suffering that are not a result of illness . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> on the other hand , there are fields that intersect with medical anthropology in terms of research methodology and theoretical production , such as cultural psychiatry and transcultural psychiatry or ethnopsychiatry . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> nutritional anthropology is a synthetic concept that deals with the interplay between economic systems , nutritional status and food security , and how changes in the former affect the latter . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> if economic and environmental changes in a community affect access to food , food security , and dietary health , then this interplay between culture and biology is in turn connected to broader historical and economic trends associated with globalization . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> nutritional status affects overall health status , work performance potential , and the overall potential for economic development ( either in terms of human development or traditional western models ) for any given group of people . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> psychological anthropology is an interdisciplinary subfield of anthropology that studies the interaction of cultural and mental processes . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> this subfield tends to focus on ways in which humans development and enculturation within a particular cultural group with its own history , language , practices , and conceptual categories shape processes of human cognition , emotion , perception , motivation , and mental health . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> it also examines how the understanding of cognition , emotion , motivation , and similar psychological processes inform or constrain our models of cultural and social processes . <end>
<start> cognitive anthropology seeks to explain patterns of shared knowledge , cultural innovation , and transmission over time and space using the methods and theories of the cognitive sciences ( especially experimental psychology and evolutionary biology ) often through close collaboration with historians , ethnographers , archaeologists , linguists , musicologists and other specialists engaged in the description and interpretation of cultural forms .
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> cognitive anthropology is concerned with what people from different groups know and how that implicit knowledge changes the way people perceive and relate to the world around them . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> transpersonal anthropology studies the relationship between altered states of consciousness and culture . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> as with transpersonal psychology , the field is much concerned with altered states of consciousness ( asc ) and transpersonal experience . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> however , the field differs from mainstream transpersonal psychology in taking more cognizance of cross cultural issues for instance , the roles of myth , ritual , diet , and texts in evoking and interpreting extraordinary experiences . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> political anthropology concerns the structure of political systems , looked at from the basis of the structure of societies . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> political anthropology developed as a discipline concerned primarily with politics in stateless societies , a new development started from the 1960s , and is still unfolding anthropologists started increasingly to study more complex social settings in which the presence of states , bureaucracies and markets entered both ethnographic accounts and analysis of local phenomena . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the turn towards complex societies meant that political themes were taken up at two main levels . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> firstly , anthropologists continued to study political organization and political phenomena that lay outside the state regulated sphere ( as in patron client relations or tribal political organization ) . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> secondly , anthropologists slowly started to develop a disciplinary concern with states and their institutions ( and on the relationship between formal and informal political institutions ) . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> an anthropology of the state developed , and it is a most thriving field today . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> geertz comparative work on negara , the balinese state , is an early , famous example . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> legal anthropology or anthropology of law specializes in the cross cultural study of social ordering . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> earlier legal anthropological research often focused more narrowly on conflict management , crime , sanctions , or formal regulation . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> more recent applications include issues such as human rights , legal pluralism , and political uprisings . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> public anthropology was created by robert borofsky , a professor at hawaii pacific university , to demonstrate the ability of anthropology and anthropologists to effectively address problems beyond the discipline illuminating larger social issues of our times as well as encouraging broad , public conversations about them with the explicit goal of fostering social change . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> cyborg anthropology originated as a sub focus group within the american anthropological association s annual meeting in 1993 . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the sub group was very closely related to sts and the society for the social studies of science . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> donna haraway s 1985 cyborg manifesto could be considered the founding document of cyborg anthropology by first exploring the philosophical and sociological ramifications of the term . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> cyborg anthropology studies humankind and its relations with the technological systems it has built , specifically modern technological systems that have reflexively shaped notions of what it means to be human beings . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> digital anthropology is the study of the relationship between humans and digital era technology , and extends to various areas where anthropology and technology intersect . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> it is sometimes grouped with sociocultural anthropology , and sometimes considered part of material culture . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the field is new , and thus has a variety of names with a variety of emphases . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> these include techno anthropology , digital ethnography , cyberanthropology , and virtual anthropology . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> ecological anthropology is defined as the study of cultural adaptations to environments . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the sub field is also defined as , the study of relationships between a population of humans and their biophysical environment . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the focus of its research concerns how cultural beliefs and practices helped human populations adapt to their environments , and how their environment across space and time . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the contemporary perspective of environmental anthropology , and arguably at least the backdrop , if not the focus of most of the ethnographies and cultural fieldworks of today , is political ecology . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> many characterize this new perspective as more informed with culture , politics and power , globalization , localized issues , century anthropology and more . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the focus and data interpretation is often used for arguments for against or creation of policy , and to prevent corporate exploitation and damage of land . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> often , the observer has become an active part of the struggle either directly ( organizing , participation ) or indirectly ( articles , documentaries , books , ethnographies ) . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> such is the case with environmental justice advocate melissa checker and her relationship with the people of hyde park . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> ethnohistory is the study of ethnographic cultures and indigenous customs by examining historical records . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> it is also the study of the history of various ethnic groups that may or may not exist today . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> ethnohistory uses both historical and ethnographic data as its foundation . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> its historical methods and materials go beyond the standard use of documents and manuscripts . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> practitioners recognize the utility of such source material as maps , music , paintings , photography , folklore , oral tradition , site exploration , archaeological materials , museum collections , enduring customs , language , and place names . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the anthropology of religion involves the study of religious institutions in relation to other social institutions , and the comparison of religious beliefs and practices across cultures . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> modern anthropology assumes that there is complete continuity between magical thinking and religion , and that every religion is a cultural product , created by the human community that worships it . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> urban anthropology is concerned with issues of urbanization , poverty , and neoliberalism . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> ulf hannerz quotes a 1960s remark that traditional anthropologists were a notoriously agoraphobic lot , anti urban by definition . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> various social processes in the western world as well as in the third world ( the latter being the habitual focus of attention of anthropologists ) brought the attention of specialists in other cultures closer to their homes . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> there are two main approaches to urban anthropology examining the types of cities or examining the social issues within the cities . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> these two methods are overlapping and dependent of each other . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> by defining different types of cities , one would use social factors as well as economic and political factors to categorize the cities . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> by directly looking at the different social issues , one would also be studying how they affect the dynamic of the city . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> anthrozoology ( also known as human animal studies ) is the study of interaction between living things . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> it is an interdisciplinary field that overlaps with a number of other disciplines , including anthropology , ethology , medicine , psychology , veterinary medicine and zoology . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> a major focus of anthrozoologic research is the quantifying of the positive effects of human animal relationships on either party and the study of their interactions . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> it includes scholars from a diverse range of fields , including anthropology , sociology , biology , and philosophy . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> biocultural anthropology is the scientific exploration of the relationships between human biology and culture . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> physical anthropologists throughout the first half of the 20th century viewed this relationship from a racial perspective that is , from the assumption that typological human biological differences lead to cultural differences . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> after world war ii the emphasis began to shift toward an effort to explore the role culture plays in shaping human biology . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> evolutionary anthropology is the interdisciplinary study of the evolution of human physiology and human behaviour and the relation between hominins and non hominin primates . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> evolutionary anthropology is based in natural science and social science , combining the human development with socioeconomic factors . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> evolutionary anthropology is concerned with both biological and cultural evolution of humans , past and present . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> it is based on a scientific approach , and brings together fields such as archaeology , behavioral ecology , psychology , primatology , and genetics . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> it is a dynamic and interdisciplinary field , drawing on many lines of evidence to understand the human experience , past and present . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> forensic anthropology is the application of the science of physical anthropology and human osteology in a legal setting , most often in criminal cases where the victim s remains are in the advanced stages of decomposition . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> a forensic anthropologist can assist in the identification of deceased individuals whose remains are decomposed , burned , mutilated or otherwise unrecognizable . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the adjective forensic refers to the application of this subfield of science to a court of law . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> paleoanthropology combines the disciplines of paleontology and physical anthropology . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> it is the study of ancient humans , as found in fossil hominid evidence such as petrifacted bones and footprints . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> genetics and morphology of specimens are crucially important to this field . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> markers on specimens , such as enamel fractures and dental decay on teeth , can also give insight into the behaviour and diet of past populations . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> contemporary anthropology is an established science with academic departments at most universities and colleges . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the single largest organization of anthropologists is the american anthropological association ( aaa ) , which was founded in 1903 . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> its members are anthropologists from around the globe . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in 1989 , a group of european and american scholars in the field of anthropology established the european association of social anthropologists ( easa ) which serves as a major professional organization for anthropologists working in europe . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the easa seeks to advance the status of anthropology in europe and to increase visibility of marginalized anthropological traditions and thereby contribute to the project of a global anthropology or world anthropology . <end>
<start> hundreds of other organizations exist in the various sub fields of anthropology , sometimes divided up by nation or region , and many anthropologists work with collaborators in other disciplines , such as geology , physics , zoology , paleontology , anatomy , music theory , art history , sociology and so on , belonging to professional societies in those disciplines as well
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> as the field has matured it has debated and arrived at ethical principles aimed at protecting both the subjects of anthropological research as well as the researchers themselves , and professional societies have generated codes of ethics . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> anthropologists , like other researchers ( especially historians and scientists engaged in field research ) , have over time assisted state policies and projects , especially colonialism . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> some commentators have contended as part of their quest for scientific objectivity , present day anthropologists typically urge cultural relativism , which has an influence on all the sub fields of anthropology . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> this is the notion that cultures should not be judged by another s values or viewpoints , but be examined dispassionately on their own terms . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> there should be no notions , in good anthropology , of one culture being better or worse than another culture . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> ethical commitments in anthropology include noticing and documenting genocide , infanticide , racism , mutilation ( including circumcision and subincision ) , and torture . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> topics like racism , slavery , and human sacrifice attract anthropological attention and theories ranging from nutritional deficiencies to genes to acculturation have been proposed , not to mention theories of colonialism and many others as root causes of man s inhumanity to man . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> to illustrate the depth of an anthropological approach , one can take just one of these topics , such as racism and find thousands of anthropological references , stretching across all the major and minor sub fields . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> anthropologists involvement with the u . s . government , in particular , has caused bitter controversy within the discipline . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> franz boas publicly objected to us participation in world war i , and after the war he published a brief expose and condemnation of the participation of several american archaeologists in espionage in mexico under their cover as scientists . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> but by the 1940s , many of boas anthropologist contemporaries were active in the allied war effort against the axis powers ( nazi germany , fascist italy , and imperial japan ) . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> many served in the armed forces , while others worked in intelligence ( for example , office of strategic services and the office of war information ) . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> at the same time , david h . price s work on american anthropology during the cold war provides detailed accounts of the pursuit and dismissal of several anthropologists from their jobs for communist sympathies . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> attempts to accuse anthropologists of complicity with the cia and government intelligence activities during the vietnam war years have turned up surprisingly little . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> many anthropologists ( students and teachers ) were active in the antiwar movement . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> numerous resolutions condemning the war in all its aspects were passed overwhelmingly at the annual meetings of the american anthropological association ( aaa ) . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> professional anthropological bodies often object to the use of anthropology for the benefit of the state . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> their codes of ethics or statements may proscribe anthropologists from giving secret briefings . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the association of social anthropologists of the uk and commonwealth ( asa ) has called certain scholarship ethically dangerous . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the principles of professional responsibility issued by the american anthropological association and amended through november 1986 stated that in relation with their own government and with host governments . . . no secret research , no secret reports or debriefings of any kind should be agreed to or given . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the current principles of professional responsibility does not make explicit mention of ethics surrounding state interactions . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> anthropologists , along with other social scientists , are working with the us military as part of the us army s strategy in afghanistan . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the christian science monitor reports that counterinsurgency efforts focus on better grasping and meeting local needs in afghanistan , under the human terrain system ( hts ) program in addition , hts teams are working with the us military in iraq . <end>
<start> in 2009 , the american anthropological association s commission on the engagement of anthropology with the us security and intelligence communities released its final report concluding , in part , that , when ethnographic investigation is determined by military missions , not subject to external review , where data collection occurs in the context of war , integrated into the goals of counterinsurgency
<start> in summary , while we stress that constructive engagement between anthropology and the military is possible , ceaussic suggests that the aaa emphasize the incompatibility of hts with disciplinary ethics and practice for job seekers and that it further recognize the problem of allowing hts to define the meaning of anthropology within dod . before wwii british social anthropology and american cultural anthropology
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> after the war , enough british and american anthropologists borrowed ideas and methodological approaches from one another that some began to speak of them collectively as sociocultural anthropology . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> there are several characteristics that tend to unite anthropological work . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> one of the central characteristics is that anthropology tends to provide a comparatively more holistic account of phenomena and tends to be highly empirical . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the quest for holism leads most anthropologists to study a particular place , problem or phenomenon in detail , using a variety of methods , over a more extensive period than normal in many parts of academia . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in the 1990s and 2000s , calls for clarification of what constitutes a culture , of how an observer knows where his or her own culture ends and another begins , and other crucial topics in writing anthropology were heard . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> these dynamic relationships , between what can be observed on the ground , as opposed to what can be observed by compiling many local observations remain fundamental in any kind of anthropology , whether cultural , biological , linguistic or archaeological . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> biological anthropologists are interested in both human variation and in the possibility of human universals ( behaviors , ideas or concepts shared by virtually all human cultures ) . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> they use many different methods of study , but modern population genetics , participant observation and other techniques often take anthropologists into the field , which means traveling to a community in its own setting , to do something called fieldwork . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> on the biological or physical side , human measurements , genetic samples , nutritional data may be gathered and published as articles or monographs . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> along with dividing up their project by theoretical emphasis , anthropologists typically divide the world up into relevant time periods and geographic regions . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> human time on earth is divided up into relevant cultural traditions based on material , such as the paleolithic and the neolithic , of particular use in archaeology . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> further cultural subdivisions according to tool types , such as olduwan or mousterian or levalloisian help archaeologists and other anthropologists in understanding major trends in the human past . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> anthropologists and geographers share approaches to culture regions as well , since mapping cultures is central to both sciences . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> by making comparisons across cultural traditions ( time based ) and cultural regions ( space based ) , anthropologists have developed various kinds of comparative method , a central part of their science . <end>
<start> because anthropology developed from so many different enterprises ( see history of anthropology ) , including but not limited to fossil hunting , exploring , documentary film making , paleontology , primatology , antiquity dealings and curatorship , philology , etymology , genetics , regional analysis , ethnology , history , philosophy , and religious studies , it is difficult to characterize the
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> some authors argue that anthropology originated and developed as the study of other cultures , both in terms of time ( past societies ) and space ( non european non western societies ) . <end>
<pad> <pad> <start> for example , the classic of urban anthropology , ulf hannerz in the introduction to his seminal exploring the city inquiries toward an urban anthropology mentions that the third world had habitually received most of attention anthropologists who traditionally specialized in other cultures looked for them far away and started to look across the tracks only in late 1960s . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> now there exist many works focusing on peoples and topics very close to the author s home . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> it is also argued that other fields of study , like history and sociology , on the contrary focus disproportionately on the west . <end>
<start> in france , the study of western societies has been traditionally left to sociologists , but this is increasingly changing , starting in the 1970s from scholars like isac chiva and journals like terrain ( fieldwork ) , and developing with the center founded by marc auge ( le centre d anthropologie des mondes contemporains , the anthropological research center of contemporary societies
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> since the 1980s it has become common for social and cultural anthropologists to set ethnographic research in the north atlantic region , frequently examining the connections between locations rather than limiting research to a single locale . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> there has also been a related shift toward broadening the focus beyond the daily life of ordinary people increasingly , research is set in settings such as scientific laboratories , social movements , governmental and nongovernmental organizations and businesses . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> agricultural science agricultural science is a broad multidisciplinary field of biology that encompasses the parts of exact , natural , economic and social sciences that are used in the practice and understanding of agriculture . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> ( veterinary science , but not animal science , is often excluded from the definition . ) <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the three terms are often confused . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> however , they cover different concepts agricultural sciences include research and development on agricultural biotechnology is a specific area of agricultural science involving the use of scientific tools and techniques , including genetic engineering , molecular markers , molecular diagnostics , vaccines , and tissue culture , to modify living organisms plants , animals , and microorganisms . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> one of the most common yield reducers is because of fertilizer not being applied in slightly higher quantities during transition period , the time it takes the soil to rebuild its aggregates and organic matter . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> yields will decrease temporarily because of nitrogen being immobilized in the crop residue , which can take a few months to several years to decompose , depending on the crop s c to n ratio and the local environment . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in the 18th century , johann friedrich mayer conducted experiments on the use of gypsum ( hydrated calcium sulphate ) as a fertilizer . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in 1843 , john lawes and joseph henry gilbert began a set of long term field experiments at rothamsted research station in england some of them are still running . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in the united states , a scientific revolution in agriculture began with the hatch act of 1887 , which used the term agricultural science . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the hatch act was driven by farmers interest in knowing the constituents of early artificial fertilizer . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the smith hughes act of 1917 shifted agricultural education back to its vocational roots , but the scientific foundation had been built . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> after 1906 , public expenditures on agricultural research in the us exceeded private expenditures for the next 44 years . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> alchemy alchemy ( from arabic al kimiya ) was an ancient branch of natural philosophy , a philosophical and protoscientific tradition practised throughout europe , africa , and asia , originating in greco roman egypt in the first few centuries . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> alchemists attempted to purify , mature , and perfect certain materials . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> common aims were chrysopoeia , the transmutation of base metals ( e . g . , lead ) into noble metals ( particularly gold ) the creation of an elixir of immortality the creation of panaceas able to cure any disease and the development of an alkahest , a universal solvent . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the perfection of the human body and soul was thought to permit or result from the alchemical magnum opus and , in the hellenistic and western mystery tradition , the achievement of gnosis . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in europe , the creation of a philosopher s stone was variously connected with all of these projects . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in english , the term is often limited to descriptions of european alchemy , but similar practices existed in the far east , the indian subcontinent , and the muslim world . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in europe , following the 12th century renaissance produced by the translation of medieval islamic works on science and the rediscovery of aristotelian philosophy , alchemists played a significant role in early modern science ( particularly chemistry and medicine ) . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> islamic and european alchemists developed a structure of basic laboratory techniques , theory , terminology , and experimental method , some of which are still in use today . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> however , they continued antiquity s belief in four elements and guarded their work in secrecy including cyphers and cryptic symbolism . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> their work was guided by hermetic principles related to magic , mythology , and religion . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> modern discussions of alchemy are generally split into an examination of its exoteric practical applications and its esoteric spiritual aspects , despite the arguments of scholars like holmyard and von franz that they should be understood as complementary . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the former is pursued by historians of the physical sciences who examine the subject in terms of early chemistry , medicine , and charlatanism , and the philosophical and religious contexts in which these events occurred . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the latter interests historians of esotericism , psychologists , and some philosophers and spiritualists . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the subject has also made an ongoing impact on literature and the arts . <end>
<pad> <pad> <start> despite this split , which von franz believes has existed since the western traditions origin in a mix of greek philosophy that was mixed with egyptian and mesopotamian technology , numerous sources have stressed an integration of esoteric and exoteric approaches to alchemy as far back as pseudo democritus s first century on physical and mystical matters ( ) . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> although alchemy is popularly associated with magic , historian lawrence m . principe argues that recent historical research has revealed that medieval and early modern alchemy embraced a much more varied set of ideas , goals , techniques , and practices <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> most readers probably are aware of several common claims about alchemy for example , . . . that it is akin to magic , or that its practice then or now is essentially deceptive . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> these ideas about alchemy emerged during the eighteenth century or after . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> while each of them might have limited validity within a narrow context , none of them is an accurate depiction of alchemy in general . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the word alchemy comes from old french alquemie , alkimie , used in medieval latin as alchymia . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> this name was itself brought from the arabic word al kimiya ( or ) composed of two parts the late greek term khemeia ( ) , khemia ( ) , meaning to fuse or cast a metal , and the arabic definite article al ( ) , <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> meaning the . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> together this association can be interpreted as the process of transmutation by which to fuse or reunite with the divine or original form . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> its roots can be traced to the egyptian name keme ( hieroglyphic khmi ) , meaning black earth which refers to the fertile and auriferous soil of the nile valley , as opposed to red desert sand . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> according to the egyptologist wallis budge , the arabic word al kimiya actually means the egyptian science , borrowing from the coptic word for egypt , keme ( or its equivalent in the mediaeval bohairic dialect of coptic , kheme ) . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> this coptic word derives from demotic kmi , itself from ancient egyptian kmt . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the ancient egyptian word referred to both the country and the colour black ( egypt was the black land , by contrast with the red land , the surrounding desert ) so this etymology could also explain the nickname egyptian black arts . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> however , according to mahn , this theory may be an example of folk etymology . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> assuming an egyptian origin , chemistry is defined as follows thus , according to budge and others , chemistry derives from an egyptian word khemein or khemia , preparation of black powder , ultimately derived from the name khem , egypt . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> a decree of diocletian , written about 300 ad in greek , speaks against the ancient writings of the egyptians , which treat of the khemia transmutation of gold and silver . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the medieval latin form was influenced by greek chymeia ( ) meaning mixture and referring to pharmaceutical chemistry . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> alchemy is several philosophical traditions spanning some four millennia and three continents . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> these traditions general penchant for cryptic and symbolic language makes it hard to trace their mutual influences and genetic relationships . <end>
<start> one can distinguish at least three major strands , which appear to be largely independent , at least in their earlier stages chinese alchemy , centered in china and its zone of cultural influence indian alchemy , centered on the indian subcontinent and western alchemy , which occurred around the mediterranean and whose center has shifted over the millennia from greco roman egypt
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> chinese alchemy was closely connected to taoism and indian alchemy with the dharmic faiths , whereas western alchemy developed its own philosophical system that was largely independent of , but influenced by , various western religions . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> it is still an open question whether these three strands share a common origin , or to what extent they influenced each other . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the start of western alchemy may generally be traced to ancient and hellenistic egypt , where the city of alexandria was a center of alchemical knowledge , and retained its pre eminence through most of the greek and roman periods . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> here , elements of technology , religion , mythology , and hellenistic philosophy , each with their own much longer histories , combined to form the earliest known records of alchemy in the west . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> zosimos of panopolis wrote the oldest known books on alchemy , while mary the jewess is credited as being the first non fictitious western alchemist . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> they wrote in greek and lived in egypt under roman rule . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> mythology zosimos of panopolis asserted that alchemy dated back to pharaonic egypt where it was the domain of the priestly class , though there is little to no evidence for his assertion . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> alchemical writers used classical figures from greek , roman , and egyptian mythology to illuminate their works and allegorize alchemical transmutation . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> these included the pantheon of gods related to the classical planets , isis , osiris , jason , and many others . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the central figure in the mythology of alchemy is hermes trismegistus ( or thrice great hermes ) . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> his name is derived from the god thoth and his greek counterpart hermes . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> hermes and his caduceus or serpent staff , were among alchemy s principal symbols . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> according to clement of alexandria , he wrote what were called the forty two books of hermes , covering all fields of knowledge . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the hermetica of thrice great hermes is generally understood to form the basis for western alchemical philosophy and practice , called the hermetic philosophy by its early practitioners . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> these writings were collected in the first centuries of the common era . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> technology <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the dawn of western alchemy is sometimes associated with that of metallurgy , extending back to 3500 . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> many writings were lost when the emperor diocletian ordered the burning of alchemical books after suppressing a revolt in alexandria ( 292 ) . <end>
