<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> few original egyptian documents on alchemy have survived , most notable among them the stockholm papyrus and the leyden papyrus x . dating from 250 300 , they contained recipes for dyeing and making artificial gemstones , cleaning and fabricating pearls , and manufacturing of imitation gold and silver . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> these writings lack the mystical , philosophical elements of alchemy , but do contain the works of bolus of mendes ( or pseudo democritus ) , which aligned these recipes with theoretical knowledge of astrology and the classical elements . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> between the time of bolus and zosimos , the change took place that transformed this metallurgy into a hermetic art . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> philosophy alexandria acted as a melting pot for philosophies of pythagoreanism , platonism , stoicism and gnosticism which formed the origin of alchemy s character . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> an important example of alchemy s roots in greek philosophy , originated by empedocles and developed by aristotle , was that all things in the universe were formed from only four elements earth , air , water , and fire . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> according to aristotle , each element had a sphere to which it belonged and to which it would return if left undisturbed . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the four elements of the greek were mostly qualitative aspects of matter , not quantitative , as our modern elements are . . . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> true alchemy never regarded earth , air , water , and fire as corporeal or chemical substances in the present day sense of the word . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the four elements are simply the primary , and most general , qualities by means of which the amorphous and purely quantitative substance of all bodies first reveals itself in differentiated form . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> later alchemists extensively developed the mystical aspects of this concept . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> alchemy coexisted alongside emerging christianity . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lactantius believed hermes trismegistus had prophesied its birth . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> st augustine later affirmed this in the 4th 5th centuries , but also condemned trismegistus for idolatry . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> examples of pagan , christian , and jewish alchemists can be found during this period . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> most of the greco roman alchemists preceding zosimos are known only by pseudonyms , such as moses , isis , cleopatra , democritus , and ostanes . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> others authors such as komarios , and chymes , we only know through fragments of text . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> after 400 , greek alchemical writers occupied themselves solely in commenting on the works of these predecessors . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> by the middle of the 7th century alchemy was almost an entirely mystical discipline . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> it was at that time that khalid ibn yazid sparked its migration from alexandria to the islamic world , facilitating the translation and preservation of greek alchemical texts in the 8th and 9th centuries . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the 2nd millennium bce text <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> vedas describe a connection between eternal life and gold . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the use of mercury for alchemy is first documented in the 3rd or 4th century bce text arthashastra . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> buddhist texts from the 2nd to 5th centuries mention the transmutation of base metals to gold . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> greek alchemy may have been introduced to ancient india through the invasions of alexander the great in 325 , and kingdoms that were culturally influenced by the greeks like gandhara , although hard evidence for this is lacking . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the 11th century persian chemist and physician abu rayhan biruni , who visited gujarat as part of the court of mahmud of ghazni , reported that they <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the goals of alchemy in india included the creation of a divine body ( sanskrit divya deham ) and immortality while still embodied ( sanskrit jivan mukti ) . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> sanskrit alchemical texts include much material on the manipulation of mercury and sulphur , that are homologized with the semen of the god siva and the menstrual blood of the goddess devi . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> some early alchemical writings seem to have their origins in the kaula tantric schools associated to the teachings of the personality of matsyendranath . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> other early writings are found in the jaina medical treatise kalyanakarakam of ugraditya , written in south india in the early 9th century . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> two famous early indian alchemical authors were nagarjuna siddha and nityanatha siddha . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> nagarjuna siddha was a buddhist monk . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> his book , rasendramangalam , is an example of indian alchemy and medicine . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> nityanatha siddha wrote rasaratnakara , also a highly influential work . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in sanskrit , rasa translates to mercury , and nagarjuna siddha was said to have developed a method of converting mercury into gold . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> scholarship on indian alchemy is in the publication of the alchemical body by david gordon white . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> a modern bibliography on indian alchemical studies has been written by white . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the contents of 39 sanskrit alchemical treatises have been analysed in detail in g . jan meulenbeld s history of indian medical literature . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the discussion of these works in himl gives a summary of the contents of each work , their special features , and where possible the evidence concerning their dating . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> chapter 13 of himl , various works on rasasastra and ratnasastra ( or various works on alchemy and gems ) gives brief details of a further 655 ( six hundred and fifty five ) treatises . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in some cases meulenbeld gives notes on the contents and authorship of these works in other cases references are made only to the unpublished manuscripts of these titles . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> a great deal remains to be discovered about indian alchemical literature . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the content of the sanskrit alchemical corpus has not yet ( 2014 ) been adequately integrated into the wider general history of alchemy . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> after the fall of the roman empire , the focus of alchemical development moved to the islamic world . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> much more is known about islamic alchemy because it was better documented indeed , most of the earlier writings that have come down through the years were preserved as arabic translations . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the word alchemy itself was derived from the arabic word al kimiya ( ) . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the early islamic world was a melting pot for alchemy . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> platonic and aristotelian thought , which had already been somewhat appropriated into hermetical science , continued to be assimilated during the late 7th and early 8th centuries through syriac translations and scholarship . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in the late 8th century , jabir ibn hayyan ( latinized as geber or geberus ) introduced a new approach to alchemy , based on scientific methodology and controlled experimentation in the laboratory , in contrast to the ancient greek and egyptian alchemists whose works were often allegorical and unintelligible , with very little concern for laboratory work . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> jabir is thus considered by many to be the father of chemistry , albeit others reserve that title for robert boyle or antoine lavoisier . <end>
<start> the science historian , paul kraus , wrote jabir himself clearly recognized and proclaimed the importance of experimentation early islamic chemists such as jabir ibn hayyan , al kindi ( alkindus ) and muhammad ibn zakariya razi ( rasis or rhazes ) contributed a number of key chemical discoveries , such as the muriatic ( hydrochloric acid ) , sulfuric and nitric acids
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the discovery that aqua regia , a mixture of nitric and hydrochloric acids , could dissolve the noblest metal , gold , was to fuel the imagination of alchemists for the next millennium . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> islamic philosophers also made great contributions to alchemical hermeticism . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the most influential author in this regard was arguably jabir . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> jabir s ultimate goal was takwin , the artificial creation of life in the alchemical laboratory , up to , and including , human life . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> he analyzed each aristotelian element in terms of four basic qualities of hotness , coldness , dryness , and moistness . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> according to jabir , in each metal two of these qualities were interior and two were exterior . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> for example , lead was externally cold and dry , while gold was hot and moist . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> thus , jabir theorized , by rearranging the qualities of one metal , a different metal would result . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> by this reasoning , the search for the philosopher s stone was introduced to western alchemy . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> jabir developed an elaborate numerology whereby the root letters of a substance s name in arabic , when treated with various transformations , held correspondences to the element s physical properties . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the elemental system used in medieval alchemy also originated with jabir . <end>
<pad> <start> his original system consisted of seven elements , which included the five classical elements ( aether , air , earth , fire , and water ) in addition to two chemical elements representing the metals sulphur , the stone which burns , which characterized the principle of combustibility , and mercury , which contained the idealized principle of metallic properties . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> shortly thereafter , this evolved into eight elements , with the arabic concept of the three metallic principles sulphur giving flammability or combustion , mercury giving volatility and stability , and salt giving solidity . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the atomic theory of corpuscularianism , where all physical bodies possess an inner and outer layer of minute particles or corpuscles , also has its origins in the work of jabir . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> from the 9th to 14th centuries , alchemical theories faced criticism from a variety of practical muslim chemists , including alkindus , abu al rayhan al biruni , avicenna and ibn khaldun . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in particular , they wrote refutations against the idea of the transmutation of metals . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> whereas european alchemy eventually centered on the transmutation of base metals into noble metals , chinese alchemy had a more obvious connection to medicine . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the philosopher s stone of european alchemists can be compared to the grand elixir of immortality sought by chinese alchemists . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> however , in the hermetic view , these two goals were not unconnected , and the philosopher s stone was often equated with the universal panacea therefore , the two traditions may have had more in common than initially appears . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> black powder may have been an important invention of chinese alchemists . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> as previously stated above , chinese alchemy was more related to medicine . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> it is said that the chinese invented gunpowder while trying to find a potion for eternal life . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> described in 9th century texts and used in fireworks in china by the 10th century , it was used in cannons by 1290 . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> from china , the use of gunpowder spread to japan , the mongols , the muslim world , and europe . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> gunpowder was used by the mongols against the hungarians in 1241 , and in europe by the 14th century . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> chinese alchemy was closely connected to taoist forms of traditional chinese medicine , such as acupuncture and moxibustion . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in the early song dynasty , followers of this taoist idea ( chiefly the elite and upper class ) would ingest mercuric sulfide , which , though tolerable in low levels , led many to suicide . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> thinking that this consequential death would lead to freedom and access to the taoist heavens , the ensuing deaths encouraged people to eschew this method of alchemy in favor of external sources ( the aforementioned tai chi chuan , mastering of the qi , etc . ) <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the introduction of alchemy to latin europe may be dated to 11 february 1144 , with the completion of robert of chester s translation of the arabic book of the composition of alchemy . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> although european craftsmen and technicians preexisted , robert notes in his preface that alchemy was unknown in latin europe at the time of his writing . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the translation of arabic texts concerning numerous disciplines including alchemy flourished in 12th century toledo , spain , through contributors like gerard of cremona and adelard of bath . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> translations of the time included the turba philosophorum , and the works of avicenna and al razi . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> these brought with them many new words to the european vocabulary for which there was no previous latin equivalent . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> alcohol , carboy , elixir , and athanor are examples . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> meanwhile , theologian contemporaries of the translators made strides towards the reconciliation of faith and experimental rationalism , thereby priming europe for the influx of alchemical thought . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the 11th century st anselm put forth the opinion that faith and rationalism were compatible and encouraged rationalism in a christian context . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in the early 12th century , peter abelard followed anselm s work , laying down the foundation for acceptance of aristotelian thought before the first works of aristotle had reached the west . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in the early 13th century , robert grosseteste used abelard s methods of analysis and added the use of observation , experimentation , and conclusions when conducting scientific investigations . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> grosseteste also did much work to reconcile platonic and aristotelian thinking . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> through much of the 12th and 13th centuries , alchemical knowledge in europe remained centered on translations , and new latin contributions were not made . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the efforts of the translators were succeeded by that of the encyclopaedists . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in the 13th century , albertus magnus and roger bacon were the most notable of these , their work summarizing and explaining the newly imported alchemical knowledge in aristotelian terms . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> albertus magnus , a dominican friar , is known to have written works such as the book of minerals where he observed and commented on the operations and theories of alchemical authorities like hermes and democritus and unnamed alchemists of his time . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> albertus critically compared these to the writings of aristotle and avicenna , where they concerned the transmutation of metals . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> from the time shortly after his death through to the 15th century , more than 28 alchemical tracts were misattributed to him , a common practice giving rise to his reputation as an accomplished alchemist . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> likewise , alchemical texts have been attributed to albert s student thomas aquinas . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> roger bacon , a franciscan friar who wrote on a wide variety of topics including optics , comparative linguistics , and medicine , composed his great work ( ) for as part of a project towards rebuilding the medieval university curriculum to include the new learning of his time . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> while alchemy was not more important to him than other sciences and he did not produce allegorical works on the topic , he did consider it and astrology to be important parts of both natural philosophy and theology and his contributions advanced alchemy s connections to soteriology and christian theology . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> bacon s writings integrated morality , salvation , alchemy , and the prolongation of life . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> his correspondence with clement highlighted this , noting the importance of alchemy to the papacy . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> like the greeks before him , bacon acknowledged the division of alchemy into practical and theoretical spheres . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> he noted that the theoretical lay outside the scope of aristotle , the natural philosophers , and all latin writers of his time . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the practical , however , confirmed the theoretical thought experiment , and bacon advocated its uses in natural science and medicine . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in later european legend , however , bacon became an archmage . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in particular , along with albertus magnus , he was credited with the forging of a brazen head capable of answering its owner s questions . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> soon after bacon , the influential work of pseudo geber ( sometimes identified as paul of taranto ) appeared . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> his summa perfectionis remained a staple summary of alchemical practice and theory through the medieval and renaissance periods . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> it was notable for its inclusion of practical chemical operations alongside sulphur mercury theory , and the unusual clarity with which they were described . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> by the end of the 13th century , alchemy had developed into a fairly structured system of belief . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <start> adepts believed in the macrocosm microcosm theories of hermes , that is to say , they believed that processes that affect minerals and other substances could have an effect on the human body ( for example , if one could learn the secret of purifying gold , one could use the technique to purify the human soul ) . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> they believed in the four elements and the four qualities as described above , and they had a strong tradition of cloaking their written ideas in a labyrinth of coded jargon set with traps to mislead the uninitiated . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> finally , the alchemists practiced their art they actively experimented with chemicals and made observations and theories about how the universe operated . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> their entire philosophy revolved around their belief that man s soul was divided within himself after the fall of adam . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> by purifying the two parts of man s soul , man could be reunited with god . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in the 14th century , alchemy became more accessible to europeans outside the confines of latin speaking churchmen and scholars . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> alchemical discourse shifted from scholarly philosophical debate to an exposed social commentary on the alchemists themselves . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> dante , piers plowman , and chaucer all painted unflattering pictures of alchemists as thieves and liars . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> pope john xxii s 1317 edict , spondent quas non exhibent forbade the false promises of transmutation made by pseudo alchemists . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in 1403 , henry iv of england banned the practice of multiplying metals ( although it was possible to buy a licence to attempt to make gold alchemically , and a number were granted by henry vi and edward iv ) . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> these critiques and regulations centered more around pseudo alchemical charlatanism than the actual study of alchemy , which continued with an increasingly christian tone . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the 14th century saw the christian imagery of death and resurrection employed in the alchemical texts of petrus bonus , john of rupescissa , and in works written in the name of raymond lull and arnold of villanova . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> nicolas flamel is a well known alchemist , but a good example of pseudepigraphy , the practice of giving your works the name of someone else , usually more famous . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> although the historical flamel existed , the writings and legends assigned to him only appeared in 1612 . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> flamel was not a religious scholar as were many of his predecessors , and his entire interest in the subject revolved around the pursuit of the philosopher s stone . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> his work spends a great deal of time describing the processes and reactions , but never actually gives the formula for carrying out the transmutations . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> most of his work was aimed at gathering alchemical knowledge that had existed before him , especially as regarded the philosopher s stone . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> through the 14th and 15th centuries , alchemists were much like flamel they concentrated on looking for the philosophers stone . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> bernard trevisan and george ripley made similar contributions . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> their cryptic allusions and symbolism led to wide variations in interpretation of the art . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> during the renaissance , hermetic and platonic foundations were restored to european alchemy . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the dawn of medical , pharmaceutical , occult , and entrepreneurial branches of alchemy followed . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in the late 15th century , marsilo ficino translated the corpus hermeticum and the works of plato into latin . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> these were previously unavailable to europeans who for the first time had a full picture of the alchemical theory that bacon had declared absent . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> renaissance humanism and renaissance neoplatonism guided alchemists away from physics to refocus on mankind as the alchemical vessel . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> esoteric systems developed that blended alchemy into a broader occult hermeticism , fusing it with magic , astrology , and christian cabala . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> a key figure in this development was german heinrich cornelius agrippa ( 1486 1535 ) , who received his hermetic education in italy in the schools of the humanists . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in his de occulta philosophia , he attempted to merge kabbalah , hermeticism , and alchemy . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> he was instrumental in spreading this new blend of hermeticism outside the borders of italy . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> philippus aureolus paracelsus , ( theophrastus bombastus von hohenheim , 1493 1541 ) cast alchemy into a new form , rejecting some of agrippa s occultism and moving away from chrysopoeia . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> paracelsus pioneered the use of chemicals and minerals in medicine and wrote , many have said of alchemy , that it is for the making of gold and silver . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> for me such is not the aim , but to consider only what virtue and power may lie in medicines . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> his hermetical views were that sickness and health in the body relied on the harmony of man the microcosm and nature the macrocosm . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> he took an approach different from those before him , using this analogy not in the manner of soul purification but in the manner that humans must have certain balances of minerals in their bodies , and that certain illnesses of the body had chemical remedies that could cure them . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> paracelsian practical alchemy , especially herbal medicine and plant remedies has since been named spagyric ( a synonym for alchemy from the greek words meaning to separate and to join together , based on the latin alchemic maxim solve et coagula ) . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> iatrochemistry also refers to the pharmaceutical applications of alchemy championed by paracelsus . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> john dee ( 13 july 1527 december , 1608 ) followed agrippa s occult tradition . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> although better known for angel summoning , divination , and his role as astrologer , cryptographer , and consultant to queen elizabeth <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> i , dee s alchemical monas hieroglyphica , written in 1564 was his most popular and influential work . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> his writing portrayed alchemy as a sort of terrestrial astronomy in line with the hermetic axiom as above so below . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> during the 17th century , a short lived supernatural interpretation of alchemy became popular , including support by fellows of the royal society robert boyle and elias ashmole . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> proponents of the supernatural interpretation of alchemy believed that the philosopher s stone might be used to summon and communicate with angels . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> entrepreneurial opportunities were common for the alchemists of renaissance europe . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> alchemists were contracted by the elite for practical purposes related to mining , medical services , and the production of chemicals , medicines , metals , and gemstones . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> rudolf ii , holy roman emperor , in the late 16th century , famously received and sponsored various alchemists at his court in prague , including dee and his associate edward kelley . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> king james iv of scotland , julius , duke of brunswick luneburg , henry v , duke of brunswick luneburg , augustus , elector of saxony , julius echter von mespelbrunn , and maurice , landgrave of hesse kassel all contracted alchemists . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> john s son arthur dee worked as a court physician to michael i of russia and charles <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> i of england but also compiled the alchemical book fasciculus chemicus . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> although most of these appointments were legitimate , the trend of pseudo alchemical fraud continued through the renaissance . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> betruger would use sleight of hand , or claims of secret knowledge to make money or secure patronage . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> legitimate mystical and medical alchemists such as michael maier and heinrich khunrath wrote about fraudulent transmutations , distinguishing themselves from the con artists . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> false alchemists were sometimes prosecuted for fraud . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the terms chemia and alchemia were used as synonyms in the early modern period , and the differences between alchemy , chemistry and small scale assaying and metallurgy were not as neat as in the present day . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> there were important overlaps between practitioners , and trying to classify them into alchemists , chemists and craftsmen is anachronistic . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> for example , tycho brahe ( 1546 1601 ) , an alchemist better known for his astronomical and astrological investigations , had a laboratory built at his uraniborg observatory research institute . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> michael sendivogius ( micha sedziwoj , 1566 1636 ) , a polish alchemist , philosopher , medical doctor and pioneer of chemistry wrote mystical works but is also credited with distilling oxygen in a lab sometime around 1600 . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> sendivogious taught his technique to cornelius drebbel who , in 1621 , applied this in a submarine . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> isaac newton devoted considerably more of his writing to the study of alchemy ( see isaac newton s occult studies ) than he did to either optics or physics . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> other early modern alchemists who were eminent in their other studies include robert boyle , and jan baptist van helmont . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> their hermeticism complemented rather than precluded their practical achievements in medicine and science . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the decline of european alchemy was brought about by the rise of modern science with its emphasis on rigorous quantitative experimentation and its disdain for ancient wisdom . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> although the seeds of these events were planted as early as the 17th century , alchemy still flourished for some two hundred years , and in fact may have reached its peak in the 18th century . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> as late as 1781 james price claimed to have produced a powder that could transmute mercury into silver or gold . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> early modern european alchemy continued to exhibit a diversity of theories , practices , and purposes scholastic and anti aristotelian , paracelsian and anti paracelsian , hermetic , neoplatonic , mechanistic , vitalistic , and more plus virtually every combination and compromise thereof . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> robert boyle ( 1627 1691 ) pioneered the scientific method in chemical investigations . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> he assumed nothing in his experiments and compiled every piece of relevant data . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> boyle would note the place in which the experiment was carried out , the wind characteristics , the position of the sun and moon , and the barometer reading , all just in case they proved to be relevant . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> this approach eventually led to the founding of modern chemistry in the 18th and 19th centuries , based on revolutionary discoveries of lavoisier and john dalton . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> beginning around 1720 , a rigid distinction was drawn between alchemy and chemistry for the first time . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> by the 1740s , alchemy was now restricted to the realm of gold making , leading to the popular belief that alchemists were charlatans , and the tradition itself nothing more than a fraud . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in order to protect the developing science of modern chemistry from the negative censure of which alchemy was being subjected , academic writers during the scientific enlightenment attempted , for the sake of survival , to divorce and separate the new chemistry from the old practices of alchemy . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> this move was mostly successful , and the consequences of this continued into the 19th and 20th centuries , and even to the present day . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> during the occult revival of the early 19th century , alchemy received new attention as an occult science . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the esoteric or occultist school , which arose during the 19th century , held ( and continues to hold ) the view that the substances and operations mentioned in alchemical literature are to be interpreted in a spiritual sense , and it downplays the role of the alchemy as a practical tradition or protoscience . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> this interpretation further forwarded the view that alchemy is an art primarily concerned with spiritual enlightenment or illumination , as opposed to the physical manipulation of apparatus and chemicals , and claims that the obscure language of the alchemical texts were an allegorical guise for spiritual , moral or mystical processes . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in the 19th century revival of alchemy , the two most seminal figures were mary anne atwood and ethan allen hitchcock , who independently published similar works regarding spiritual alchemy . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> both forwarded a completely esoteric view of alchemy , as atwood claimed no modern art or chemistry , notwithstanding all its surreptitious claims , has any thing in common with alchemy . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> atwood s work influenced subsequent authors of the occult revival including eliphas levi , arthur edward waite , and rudolf steiner . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> hitchcock , in his remarks upon alchymists ( 1855 ) attempted to make a case for his spiritual interpretation with his claim that the alchemists wrote about a spiritual discipline under a materialistic guise in order to avoid accusations of blasphemy from the church and state . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in 1845 , baron carl reichenbach , published his studies on odic force , a concept with some similarities to alchemy , but his research did not enter the mainstream of scientific discussion . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in 1946 , louis cattiaux published the message retrouve , a work that was at once philosophical , mystical and highly influenced by alchemy . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in his lineage , many researchers , including emmanuel and charles d hooghvorst , are updating alchemical studies in france and belgium . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> several women appear in the earliest history of alchemy . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> michael maier names mary the jewess , cleopatra the alchemist and taphnutia as the four women who knew how to make the philosopher s stone . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> zosimos sister theosebia ( later known as euthica the arab ) and isis <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the prophetess also played a role in early alchemical texts . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the first alchemist whose name we know is said to have been mary the jewess ( c . 200 a . d . ) . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> early sources claim that mary ( or maria ) devised a number of improvements to alchemical equipment and tools as well as novel techniques in chemistry . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> her best known advances were in heating and distillation processes . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the laboratory water bath , known eponymously ( especially in france ) as the bain marie , is said to have been invented or at least improved by her . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> essentially a double boiler , it was ( and is ) used in chemistry for processes that require gentle heating . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the tribikos ( a modified distillation apparatus ) and the kerotakis ( a more intricate apparatus used especially for sublimations ) are two other advancements in the process of distillation that are credited to her . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the occasional claim that mary was the first to discover hydrochloric acid is not accepted by most authorities . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> although we have no writing from mary herself , she is known from the early fourth century writings of zosimos of panopolis . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> due to the proliferation of pseudepigrapha and anonymous works , it is difficult to know which of the alchemists were actually women . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> after the greco roman period , women s names appear less frequently in the alchemical literature . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> women vacate the history of alchemy during the medieval and renaissance periods , aside from the fictitious account of perenelle flamel . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> mary anne atwood s a suggestive inquiry into the hermetic mystery ( 1850 ) marks their return during the nineteenth century occult revival . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the history of alchemy has become a significant and recognized subject of academic study . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> as the language of the alchemists is analyzed , historians are becoming more aware of the intellectual connections between that discipline and other facets of western cultural history , such as the evolution of science and philosophy , the sociology and psychology of the intellectual communities , kabbalism , spiritualism , rosicrucianism , and other mystic movements . <end>
<pad> <start> institutions involved in this research include the chymistry of isaac newton project at indiana university , the university of exeter centre for the study of esotericism ( exeseso ) , the european society for the study of western esotericism ( esswe ) , and the university of amsterdam s sub department for the history of hermetic philosophy and related currents . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> a large collection of books on alchemy is kept in the bibliotheca philosophica hermetica in amsterdam . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> a recipe found in a mid 19th century kabbalah based book features step by step instructions on turning copper into gold . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the author attributed this recipe to an ancient manuscript he located . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> journals which publish regularly on the topic of alchemy include ambix , published by the society for the history of alchemy and chemistry , and isis , published by the history of science society . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> western alchemical theory corresponds to the worldview of late antiquity in which it was born . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> concepts were imported from neoplatonism and earlier greek cosmology . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> as such , the classical elements appear in alchemical writings , as do the seven classical planets and the corresponding seven metals of antiquity . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> similarly , the gods of the roman pantheon who are associated with these luminaries are discussed in alchemical literature . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the concepts of prima materia and anima mundi are central to the theory of the philosopher s stone . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in the eyes of a variety of esoteric and hermetic practitioners , alchemy is fundamentally spiritual . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> transmutation of lead into gold is presented as an analogy for personal transmutation , purification , and perfection . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the writings attributed to hermes trismegistus are a primary source of alchemical theory . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> he is named alchemy s founder and chief patron , authority , inspiration and guide . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> early alchemists , such as zosimos of panopolis ( c . ad 300 ) , highlight the spiritual nature of the alchemical quest , symbolic of a religious regeneration of the human soul . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> this approach continued in the middle ages , as metaphysical aspects , substances , physical states , and material processes were used as metaphors for spiritual entities , spiritual states , and , ultimately , transformation . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in this sense , the literal meanings of alchemical formulas were a blind , hiding their true spiritual philosophy . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> practitioners and patrons such as melchior cibinensis and pope innocent viii existed within the ranks of the church , while martin luther applauded alchemy for its consistency with christian teachings . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> both the transmutation of common metals into gold and the universal panacea symbolized evolution from an imperfect , diseased , corruptible , and ephemeral state toward a perfect , healthy , incorruptible , and everlasting state , so the philosopher s stone then represented a mystic key that would make this evolution possible . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> applied to the alchemist himself , the twin goal symbolized his evolution from ignorance to enlightenment , and the stone represented a hidden spiritual truth or power that would lead to that goal . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in texts that are written according to this view , the cryptic alchemical symbols , diagrams , and textual imagery of late alchemical works typically contain multiple layers of meanings , allegories , and references to other equally cryptic works and must be laboriously decoded to discover their true meaning . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in his 1766 alchemical catechism , theodore henri de tschudi denotes that the usage of the metals was merely symbolic the great work of alchemy is often described as a series of four stages represented by colors . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> due to the complexity and obscurity of alchemical literature , and the 18th century disappearance of remaining alchemical practitioners into the area of chemistry the general understanding of alchemy has been strongly influenced by several distinct and radically different interpretations . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> those focusing on the exoteric , such as historians of science lawrence m . principe and william r . newman , have interpreted the decknamen ( or code words ) of alchemy as physical substances . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> these scholars have reconstructed physicochemical experiments that they say are described in medieval and early modern texts . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> at the opposite end of the spectrum , focusing on the esoteric , scholars , such as george calian and anna marie roos , who question the reading of principe and newman , interpret these same decknamen as spiritual , religious , or psychological concepts . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> today new interpretations of alchemy are still perpetuated , sometimes merging in concepts from new age or radical environmentalism movements . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> groups like the rosicrucians and freemasons have a continued interest in alchemy and its symbolism . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> since the victorian revival of alchemy , occultists reinterpreted alchemy as a spiritual practice , involving the self transformation of the practitioner and only incidentally or not at all the transformation of laboratory substances , which has contributed to a merger of magic and alchemy in popular thought . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> traditional medicine can use the concept of the transmutation of natural substances , using pharmacological or a combination of pharmacological and spiritual techniques . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in ayurveda , the samskaras are claimed to transform heavy metals and toxic herbs in a way that removes their toxicity . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> these processes are actively used to the present day . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> spagyrists of the 20th century , albert richard riedel and jean dubuis , merged paracelsian alchemy with occultism , teaching laboratory pharmaceutical methods . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the schools they founded , les philosophes de la nature and the paracelsus research society , popularized modern spagyrics including the manufacture of herbal tinctures and products . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the courses , books , organizations , and conferences generated by their students continue to influence popular applications of alchemy as a new age medicinal practice . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> alchemical symbolism has been important in depth and analytical psychology and was revived and popularized from near extinction by the swiss psychologist carl gustav jung . <end>
<start> initially confounded and at odds with alchemy and its images , after being given a copy of the translation of the secret of the golden flower , a chinese alchemical text , by his friend richard wilhelm , jung discovered a direct correlation or parallels between the symbolic images in the alchemical drawings and the inner , symbolic images coming up in dreams
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> a process , which he called process of individuation . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> he regarded the alchemical images as symbols expressing aspects of this process of individuation of which the creation of the gold or lapis within were symbols for its origin and goal . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> together with his alchemical mystica soror , jungian swiss analyst marie louise von franz , jung began collecting all the old alchemical texts available , compiled a lexicon of key phrases with cross references and pored over them . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the volumes of work he wrote brought new light into understanding the art of transubstantiation and renewed alchemy s popularity as a symbolic process of coming into wholeness as a human being where opposites brought into contact and inner and outer , spirit and matter are reunited in the hieros gamos or divine marriage . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> his writings are influential in psychology and for persons who have an interest in understanding the importance of dreams , symbols and the unconscious archetypal forces ( archetypes ) that influence all of life . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> both von franz and jung have contributed greatly to the subject and work of alchemy and its continued presence in psychology as well as contemporary culture . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> jung wrote volumes on alchemy and his magnum opus is volume 14 of his collected works , mysterium conuinctionis . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> ralph metzner , speaking to cg jung society of seattle , 2014 , sees the historical emergence of psychedelics in the work of alchemists . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start>  <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> alchemy has had a long standing relationship with art , seen both in alchemical texts and in mainstream entertainment . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> literary alchemy appears throughout the history of english literature from shakespeare to j . k . rowling , and also the popular japanese manga full metal alchemist . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> here , characters or plot structure follow an alchemical magnum opus . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in the 14th century , chaucer began a trend of alchemical satire that can still be seen in recent fantasy works like those of terry pratchett . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> visual artists had a similar relationship with alchemy . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> while some of them used alchemy as a source of satire , others worked with the alchemists themselves or integrated alchemical thought or symbols in their work . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> music was also present in the works of alchemists and continues to influence popular performers . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in the last hundred years , alchemists have been portrayed in a magical and spagyric role in fantasy fiction , film , television , novels , comics and video games . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> alien alien primarily refers to alien ( s ) , or the alien ( s ) may also refer to <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> astronomer an astronomer is a scientist in the field of astronomy who focuses their studies on a specific question or field outside the scope of earth . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> they observe astronomical objects such as stars , planets , moons , comets , and galaxies in either observational ( by analyzing the data ) or theoretical astronomy . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> examples of topics or fields astronomers study include planetary science , solar astronomy , the origin or evolution of stars , or the formation of galaxies . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> related but distinct subjects like physical cosmology , which studies the universe as a whole . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> astronomers usually fall under either of two main types observational and theoretical . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> observational astronomers make direct observations of celestial objects and analyze the data . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in contrast , theoretical astronomers create and investigate models of things that cannot be observed . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> because it takes millions to billions of years for a system of stars or a galaxy to complete a life cycle , astronomers must observe snapshots of different systems at unique points in their evolution to determine how they form , evolve , and die . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> they use these data to create models or simulations to theorize how different celestial objects work . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> further subcategories under these two main branches of astronomy include planetary astronomy , galactic astronomy , or physical cosmology . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> historically , astronomy was more concerned with the classification and description of phenomena in the sky , while astrophysics attempted to explain these phenomena and the differences between them using physical laws . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> today , that distinction has mostly disappeared and the terms astronomer and astrophysicist are interchangeable . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> professional astronomers are highly educated individuals who typically have a ph . d . in physics or astronomy and are employed by research institutions or universities . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> they spend the majority of their time working on research , although they quite often have other duties such as teaching , building instruments , or aiding in the operation of an observatory . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the number of professional astronomers in the united states is actually quite small . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the american astronomical society , which is the major organization of professional astronomers in north america , has approximately 7 , 000 members . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> this number includes scientists from other fields such as physics , geology , and engineering , whose research interests are closely related to astronomy . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the international astronomical union comprises almost 10 , 145 members from 70 different countries who are involved in astronomical research at the ph . d . level and beyond . <end>
<pad> <pad> <start> contrary to the classical image of an old astronomer peering through a telescope through the dark hours of the night , it is far more common to use a charge coupled device ( ccd ) camera to record a long , deep exposure , allowing a more sensitive image to be created because the light is added over time . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> before ccds , photographic plates were a common method of observation . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> modern astronomers spend relatively little time at telescopes usually just a few weeks per year . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> analysis of observed phenomena , along with making predictions as to the causes of what they observe , takes the majority of observational astronomers time . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> astronomers who serve as faculty spend much of their time teaching undergraduate and graduate classes . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> most universities also have outreach programs including public telescope time and sometimes planetariums as a public service to encourage interest in the field . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> those who become astronomers usually have a broad background in maths , sciences and computing in high school . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> taking courses that teach how to research , write and present papers are also invaluable . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in college university most astronomers get a ph . d . in astronomy or physics . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> while there is a relatively low number of professional astronomers , the field is popular among amateurs . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> most cities have amateur astronomy clubs that meet on a regular basis and often host star parties . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the astronomical society of the pacific is the largest general astronomical society in the world , comprising both professional and amateur astronomers as well as educators from 70 different nations . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> like any hobby , most people who think of themselves as amateur astronomers may devote a few hours a month to stargazing and reading the latest developments in research . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> however , amateurs span the range from so called armchair astronomers to the very ambitious , who own science grade telescopes and instruments with which they are able to make their own discoveries and assist professional astronomers in research . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> ascii ascii ( ) , abbreviated from american standard code for information interchange , is a character encoding standard for electronic communication . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> ascii codes represent text in computers , telecommunications equipment , and other devices . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> most modern character encoding schemes are based on ascii , although they support many additional characters . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> ascii is the traditional name for the encoding system the internet assigned numbers authority ( iana ) prefers the updated name us ascii , which clarifies that this system was developed in the us and based on the typographical symbols predominantly in use there . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> ascii is one of the ieee milestones . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> ascii was developed from telegraph code . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> its first commercial use was as a seven bit teleprinter code promoted by bell data services . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> work on the ascii standard began on october 6 , 1960 , with the first meeting of the american standards association s ( asa ) <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> ( now the american national standards institute or ansi ) x3 . 2 subcommittee . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the first edition of the standard was published in 1963 , underwent a major revision during 1967 , and experienced its most recent update during 1986 . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> compared to earlier telegraph codes , the proposed bell code and ascii were both ordered for more convenient sorting ( i . e . , alphabetization ) of lists , and added features for devices other than teleprinters . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> originally based on the english alphabet , ascii encodes 128 specified characters into seven bit integers as shown by the ascii chart above . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> ninety five of the encoded characters are printable these include the digits 0 to 9 , lowercase letters a to z , uppercase letters a to z , and punctuation symbols . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in addition , the original ascii specification included 33 non printing control codes which originated with teletype machines most of these are now obsolete , although a few are still commonly used , such as the carriage return , line feed and tab codes . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> for example , lowercase i would be represented in the ascii encoding by binary 1101001 hexadecimal 69 ( i is the ninth letter ) decimal 105 . <end>
<pad> <start> the american standard code for information interchange ( ascii ) was developed under the auspices of a committee of the american standards association ( asa ) , called the x3 committee , by its x3 . 2 ( later x3l2 ) subcommittee , and later by that subcommittee s x3 . 2 . 4 working group ( now incits ) . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the asa became the united states of america standards institute ( usasi ) and ultimately the american national standards institute ( ansi ) . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> with the other special characters and control codes filled in , ascii was published as asa x3 . 4 1963 , leaving 28 code positions without any assigned meaning , reserved for future standardization , and one unassigned control code . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> there was some debate at the time whether there should be more control characters rather than the lowercase alphabet . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the indecision did not last long during may 1963 the ccitt working party on the new telegraph alphabet proposed to assign lowercase characters to sticks 6 and 7 , and international organization for standardization tc 97 sc 2 voted during october to incorporate the change into its draft standard . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the x3 . 2 . 4 task group voted its approval for the change to ascii at its may 1963 meeting . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> locating the lowercase letters in sticks 6 and 7 caused the characters to differ in bit pattern from the upper case by a single bit , which simplified case insensitive character matching and the construction of keyboards and printers . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the x3 committee made other changes , including other new characters ( the brace and vertical bar characters ) , renaming some control characters ( som became start of header ( soh ) ) and moving or removing others ( ru was removed ) . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> ascii was subsequently updated as usas x3 . 4 1967 , then usas x3 . 4 1968 , ansi x3 . 4 1977 , and finally , ansi x3 . 4 1986 . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> revisions of the ascii standard in the x3 . 15 standard , the x3 committee also addressed how ascii should be transmitted ( least significant bit first ) , and how it should be recorded on perforated tape . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> they proposed a 9 track standard for magnetic tape , and attempted to deal with some punched card formats . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the x3 . 2 subcommittee designed ascii based on the earlier teleprinter encoding systems . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> like other character encodings , ascii specifies a correspondence between digital bit patterns and character symbols ( i . e . graphemes and control characters ) . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> this allows digital devices to communicate with each other and to process , store , and communicate character oriented information such as written language . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> before ascii was developed , the encodings in use included 26 alphabetic characters , 10 numerical digits , and from 11 to 25 special graphic symbols . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> to include all these , and control characters compatible with the comite consultatif international telephonique et telegraphique ( <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> ccitt ) <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> international telegraph alphabet no . 2 <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> ( ita2 ) standard of 1924 , fieldata ( 1956 ) , and early ebcdic ( 1963 ) , more than 64 codes were required for ascii . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> ita2 were in turn based on the 5 bit telegraph code emile baudot invented in 1870 and patented in 1874 . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the committee debated the possibility of a shift function ( like in ita2 ) , which would allow more than 64 codes to be represented by a six bit code . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in a shifted code , some character codes determine choices between options for the following character codes . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> it allows compact encoding , but is less reliable for data transmission , as an error in transmitting the shift code typically makes a long part of the transmission unreadable . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the standards committee decided against shifting , and so ascii required at least a seven bit code . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the committee considered an eight bit code , since eight bits ( octets ) would allow two four bit patterns to efficiently encode two digits with binary coded decimal . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> however , it would require all data transmission to send eight bits when seven could suffice . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the committee voted to use a seven bit code to minimize costs associated with data transmission . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> since perforated tape at the time could record eight bits in one position , it also allowed for a parity bit for error checking if desired . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> eight bit machines ( with octets as the native data type ) that did not use parity checking typically set the eighth bit to 0 . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in some printers , the high bit was used to enable italics printing . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the code itself was patterned so that most control codes were together and all graphic codes were together , for ease of identification . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the first two so called ascii sticks ( 32 positions ) were reserved for control characters . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the space character had to come before graphics to make sorting easier , so it became position 20 for the same reason , many special signs commonly used as separators were placed before digits . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the committee decided it was important to support uppercase 64 character alphabets , and chose to pattern ascii so it could be reduced easily to a usable 64 character set of graphic codes , as was done in the dec sixbit code ( 1963 ) . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> lowercase letters were therefore not interleaved with uppercase . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> to keep options available for lowercase letters and other graphics , the special and numeric codes were arranged before the letters , and the letter a was placed in position 41 to match the draft of the corresponding british standard . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the digits 0 9 are prefixed with 011 , but the remaining 4 bits correspond to their respective values in binary , making conversion with binary coded decimal straightforward . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> many of the non alphanumeric characters were positioned to correspond to their shifted position on typewriters an important subtlety is that these were based on mechanical typewriters , not electric typewriters . <end>
<start> mechanical typewriters followed the standard set by the remington no . 2 ( 1878 ) , the first typewriter with a shift key , and the shifted values of codice 1 were codice 2 early typewriters omitted 0 and 1 , using o ( capital letter o ) and l ( lowercase letter l ) instead , but codice 3 and codice 4
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> thus , in ascii codice 5 were placed in the second stick , positions 1 5 , corresponding to the digits 1 5 in the adjacent stick . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the parentheses could not correspond to 9 and 0 , however , because the place corresponding to 0 was taken by the space character . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> this was accommodated by removing codice 6 ( underscore ) from 6 and shifting the remaining characters , which corresponded to many european typewriters that placed the parentheses with 8 and 9 . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> this discrepancy from typewriters led to bit paired keyboards , notably the teletype model 33 , which used the left shifted layout corresponding to ascii , not to traditional mechanical typewriters . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <start> electric typewriters , notably the ibm selectric ( 1961 ) , used a somewhat different layout that has become standard on computers following the ibm pc ( 1981 ) , especially model m ( 1984 ) and thus shift values for symbols on modern keyboards do not correspond as closely to the ascii table as earlier keyboards did . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the codice 7 pair also dates to the no . 2 , and the codice 8 pairs were used on some keyboards ( others , including the no . 2 , did not shift codice 9 ( comma ) or codice 10 ( full stop ) so they could be used in uppercase without unshifting ) . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> however , ascii split the codice 11 pair ( dating to no . 2 ) , and rearranged mathematical symbols ( varied conventions , commonly codice 12 ) to codice 13 . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> some common characters were not included , notably codice 14 , while codice 15 were included as diacritics for international use , and codice 16 for mathematical use , together with the simple line characters codice 17 ( in addition to common codice 18 ) . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the symbol was not used in continental europe and the committee expected it would be replaced by an accented a in the french variation , so the was placed in position 40 , right before the letter a . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the control codes felt essential for data transmission were the start of message ( som ) , end of address ( eoa ) , end of message ( eom ) , end of transmission ( eot ) , who are you ? <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> ( wru ) , are you ? <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> ( ru ) , a reserved device control ( dc0 ) , synchronous idle ( sync ) , and acknowledge ( ack ) . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> these were positioned to maximize the hamming distance between their bit patterns . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> ascii code order is also called asciibetical order . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> collation of data is sometimes done in this order rather than standard alphabetical order ( collating sequence ) . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the main deviations in ascii order are <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> an intermediate order converts uppercase letters to lowercase before comparing ascii values . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> ascii reserves the first 32 codes ( numbers 0 31 decimal ) for control characters codes originally intended not to represent printable information , but rather to control devices ( such as printers ) that make use of ascii , or to provide meta information about data streams such as those stored on magnetic tape . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> for example , character 10 represents the line feed function ( which causes a printer to advance its paper ) , and character 8 represents backspace . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> refers to control characters that do not include carriage return , line feed or white space as non whitespace control characters . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> except for the control characters that prescribe elementary line oriented formatting , ascii does not define any mechanism for describing the structure or appearance of text within a document . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> other schemes , such as markup languages , address page and document layout and formatting . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the original ascii standard used only short descriptive phrases for each control character . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the ambiguity this caused was sometimes intentional , for example where a character would be used slightly differently on a terminal link than on a data stream , and sometimes accidental , for example with the meaning of delete . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> probably the most influential single device on the interpretation of these characters was the teletype model 33 asr , which was a printing terminal with an available paper tape reader punch option . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> paper tape was a very popular medium for long term program storage until the 1980s , less costly and in some ways less fragile than magnetic tape . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in particular , the teletype model 33 machine assignments for codes 17 ( control q , dc1 , also known as xon ) , 19 ( control s , dc3 , also known as xoff ) , and 127 ( delete ) became de facto standards . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the model 33 was also notable for taking the description of control g ( code 7 , <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> bel , meaning audibly alert the operator ) literally , as the unit contained an actual bell which it rang when it received a bel character . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> because the keytop for the o key also showed a left arrow symbol ( from ascii 1963 , which had this character instead of underscore ) , a noncompliant use of code 15 ( control o , shift in ) interpreted as delete previous character was also adopted by many early timesharing systems but eventually became neglected . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> when a teletype 33 asr equipped with the automatic paper tape reader received a control s ( xoff , an abbreviation for transmit off ) , it caused the tape reader to stop receiving control q ( xon , transmit on ) caused the tape reader to resume . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> this technique became adopted by several early computer operating systems as a handshaking signal warning a sender to stop transmission because of impending overflow it persists to this day in many systems as a manual output control technique . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> on some systems control s retains its meaning but control q is replaced by a second control s to resume output . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the 33 asr also could be configured to employ control r ( dc2 ) and control t ( dc4 ) to start and stop the tape punch on some units equipped with this function , the corresponding control character lettering on the keycap above the letter was tape and tape respectively . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the teletype could not move the head backwards , so it did not put a key on the keyboard to send a bs ( backspace ) . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> instead there was a key marked that sent code 127 ( del ) . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the purpose of this key was to erase mistakes in a hand typed paper tape the operator had to push a button on the tape punch to back it up , then type the rubout , which punched all holes and replaced the mistake with a character that was intended to be ignored . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> teletypes were commonly used for the less expensive computers from digital equipment corporation , so these systems had to use the available key and thus the del code to erase the previous character . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> because of this , dec video terminals ( by default ) sent the del code for the key marked backspace while the key marked delete sent an escape sequence , while many other terminals sent bs for the backspace key . <end>
<start> the unix terminal driver could only use one code to erase the previous character , this could be set to bs or del , but not both , resulting in a long period of annoyance where users had to correct it depending on what terminal they were using ( shells that allow line editing , such as ksh , bash , and zsh
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the assumption that no key sent a bs caused control h to be used for other purposes , such as the help prefix command in gnu emacs . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> many more of the control codes have been given meanings quite different from their original ones . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the escape character ( esc , code 27 ) , for example , was intended originally to allow sending other control characters as literals instead of invoking their meaning . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> this is the same meaning of escape encountered in url encodings , c language strings , and other systems where certain characters have a reserved meaning . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> over time this meaning has been co opted and has eventually been changed . <end>
<start> in modern use , an esc sent to the terminal usually indicates the start of a command sequence usually in the form of a so called ansi escape code ( or , more properly , a control sequence introducer ) from ecma 48 ( 1972 ) and its successors , beginning with esc followed by a nowiki nowiki ( left bracket ) character
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> an esc sent from the terminal is most often used as an out of band character used to terminate an operation , as in the teco and vi text editors . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> in graphical user interface ( gui ) and windowing systems , esc generally causes an application to abort its current operation or to exit ( terminate ) altogether . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the inherent ambiguity of many control characters , combined with their historical usage , created problems when transferring plain text files between systems . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the best example of this is the newline problem on various operating systems . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> teletype machines required that a line of text be terminated with both carriage return ( which moves the printhead to the beginning of the line ) and line feed ( which advances the paper one line without moving the printhead ) . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the name carriage return comes from the fact that on a manual typewriter the carriage holding the paper moved while the position where the typebars struck the ribbon remained stationary . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> the entire carriage had to be pushed ( returned ) to the right in order to position the left margin of the paper for the next line . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> dec operating systems ( os 8 , rt 11 , rsx 11 , rsts , tops 10 , etc . ) used both characters to mark the end of a line so that the console device ( originally teletype machines ) would work . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> by the time so called glass ttys ( later called crts or terminals ) came along , the convention was so well established that backward compatibility necessitated continuing the convention . <end>
<start> when gary kildall created cp m he was inspired by some command line interface conventions used in dec s rt 11 . until the introduction of pc dos in 1981 , ibm had no hand in this because their 1970s operating systems used ebcdic instead of ascii and they were oriented toward punch card input and line printer output on which the concept
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> ibm s pc dos ( also marketed as ms dos by microsoft ) inherited the convention by virtue of being loosely based on cp m , and windows inherited it from ms dos . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> unfortunately , requiring two characters to mark the end of a line introduces unnecessary complexity and questions as to how to interpret each character when encountered alone . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> to simplify matters plain text data streams , including files , on multics used line feed ( lf ) alone as a line terminator . <end>
<pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <pad> <start> unix and unix like systems , and amiga systems , adopted this convention from multics . <end>
